reviewText: I started the game some time ago now and didn't return until recently. Having lost my save i started over on easy as i wanted to move through the game pretty quick. Admittedly easy was a mistake i should have switched to normal again as i had lost some of the challenge there. Still it was a fun game, the gadgets were impressive, the scenery seemed to fit and have that gritty feel. The GOTY version has various challenges and dlc challenges that didn't particularly interest me but i can see it giving alot more longevity to the game as well as collecting the various riddler trophys etc. Overall a good experience and can see why it was awarded a game of the year edition. I'd recommend this game.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Asylum. A game started as by Batman fans, for Batman fans as a love letter. The one that started it all. The first Arkham game has aged rather well, and is still fun to play to this day. The story in my opinion is a bit better than City, (Due to the fact that this one I didn't figure out the plot by looking at the voice actors)

The story starts like this: Batman has recently captured the Joker, who set off a large fire in Blackgate Prison, causing the Blackgate prisoners to be moved to Arkham Asylum. Batman escorts Joker personally to Arkham. While delivering him to his cell under heavy security, Joker manages to escape while Harley Quinn, has taken control over Arkham. Batman has to go after them for the first (Maybe) long night of things he could have never expected.

Combat options are very limited and not as refined compared to Arkham City, and Arkham Knight, but still has the Arkham feel to it which City and Knight just made better.

The Predator options are also much less fun compared to City due to how little gadgets there are, and no grate, vent, or quick takedowns. But, the fan favourite, the Inverted takedown is in this game.

All in all a great Batman game, and one people will remember as one of the better ones. I give this game, A 9/10
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There's not much point in writing an in depth review for Arkham Asylum given the wealth of positive reviews out there so, in short, this game makes you feel like Batman. I played using an Xbox controller and the controls and targeting system were so intuitive that there was no learning curve; I just went into Arkham and did some stealthy stuff, beat up a bunch of bad guys and propelled myself into the darkness with some crazy gadget. Job done, and I felt awesome.

The best thing I could say about this game is that while everything feels so effortless, it's also quite difficult. I don't entirely understand how they managed to do that, but keeping that balance certainly isn't easy. Arkham Asylum does this so well that you just come out of the game feeling like a hero.

I only have one bad thing to say about this game, and that is that I wanted to hang every bad guy from a gargoyle, but it's just not possible. The game even actively tried to stop me from doing so at one point, like I was a child being scolded for eating too much candy.

10/10 would have myself commited again.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Warner Bros. At first, I am not a huge fan of Batman or pretty much I am not a fan of comic books. Surprisingly, this is the Batman game that met its expectations for fans and comic book alike. The game sets in Arkham Asylum, playing as Bruce Wayne or Batman (state the obvious). The story starts where Batman is taking and apprehending Joker to the Asylum, causing it was a setup and controlling the asylum by Joker. I am not going to tell you much about the story, it's better to play the game to know about the story. Trust me, it's such a great Batman game to start with. The combat system is based on combo, score multipliers, dodges and counter attacks. There are gadgets to tackle obstacles throughout the story. You can upgrade your abilities by leveling up. Collectables all over the map (Riddler's Trophy, scarab wall and searching the answer for Riddler's challenge), like the backstory of Arkham Asylum, the interview tapes, the concept art and character bios to learn about their orginality.

+ Pros+ Rich storyline
+ Characters are obviously likeable
+ Voice acting and musical score
+ Freedom Open World (Kind of)
+ Atmosphere and graphics of the game
+ Combat system
+ Extras or Collectables

- Cons- Controls for Keyboard and Mouse are confusingly tricky

The verdict for this game's honest review is a must buy, like come on buy this game and you will love it every second, even if you are not a fan of Batman like myself. The story, the atmosphere, the voice acting, combat system and unlockables. You can find all of the extras after you finished the game and play some challenges. I don't find any game's technical flaws (unless I am a blind bat or not paying attention to details). I definitely recommend this game, just go buy the game.

Updated: June 05 2015 @ 03:00am - removing the manga next to comic books sentence and finishing touches.

reviewText:
As much as I love playing creative indie games, it is really refreshing to play a game with a huge budget where they worked closely with Nvidia to optimize the graphics and make a 3D Vision ready game. What I mean by all of this is: Batman: Arkham Asylum looks gorgeous! There were even a few scenes that had a lot of PhysX effects going on that my GTX 670 struggled with. I wouldn't have guessed that it came out in 2009. One of my biggest pet peeves is when games that look great have cutscenes that have been rendered in 720p (I'm looking at you, Mass Effect series) but the only difference I could see in Asylum was that the cutscenes were not in 3D.

I'm not a huge Batman fan, so I don't know who most of the villains are; I only learned about Two Face when I watched The Dark Knight. Arkham Asylum does a very good job of introducing the characters and giving their backgrounds. They even have a little bio section for each major character with both in-universe and real life facts about them. I could tell that most of the character designs were new takes on those characters, and I definitely think that they were done well. I found it a little odd that almost every single person in the game was ripped, but this is Batman after all.

Mark Hamill did a phenomenal job voicing the Joker. He was easily the most interesting character tho listen to, and I intentionally died a couple of times so I could listen to him taunt me.

Each main villain had a couple of levels devoted to them. My personal favorite were the Scarecrow levels because I got to relive some of the defining moments in Batman's life. By that I mean I got to see his parents die.

The gameplay is pretty basic: left-click to hit people, and right-click to counter when they try to hit you. Some enemy types switch this up a little by making you stun them first or dodging behind them before you can hit them, but ultimately it only adds one extra button that you have to hit before taking them down.

My favorite parts of the game were the rooms where there were a bunch of armed thugs in a large area, and I had to figure out how to take them down without being seen. It reminded me of the scenes in Batman Begins down by the docks where Batman did just that. Unfortunately I wasn't quite as good at it as the real Batman.

The detective puzzles" were fairly interesting
date: but usually very straightforward. I felt like I was doing less detective work and more just following a trail that the developers would only let me see if I turned on the special goggles.\n\nMy least favorite parts by far were the boss battles. They were clearly constructed exactly the same way that boss battles were made back in the 90's. I was usually stuck on a platform below the much larger boss
recommended: performing the same actions multiple times while looking for patterns in their attacks so I knew when they were vulnerable.\n\nIt took me a little over 10 hours to complete the story. It seemed like I wasn't missing much by not exploring heavily; the main missions took me all over the island. It would have been nice to have gotten more of the audio logs
hoursPlayed: which were pretty amusing
voteText: and I only found a fraction of the Riddler trophies. I'm definitely not a completionist.\n\nOverall I enjoyed the game a lot
helpfulPercent: and I would recommend that anyone who thinks Batman is the coolest play it. It's currently $20
votesHelpful: which is a pretty reasonable price."

reviewText:
Previous Superhero games before this were pretty bad (Spider-Man 2 is an exception) the stories were laughable and they often had god-awful controls and poor gameplay. Then in 2009 Batman: Arkham Asylum came out, developed by Rocksteady Studios in London as their second game. This game had a moderate amount of hype at the time (everyone was scarred this would be a failure) however upon release it gained mass appeal. Graphically the game looks great, has some awesome environments and character models. The storyline is great too (written by Paul Dini, who also the Batman: Animated Series) and features a good roster of Batman Villians, and manages to balance the story and characters pretty well. The gameplay is amazing, it features an easy to learn but difficult to master hand to hand combat system mixed with Batman gadgets, and to complement the gameplay the control scheme is great (recommend a gamepad). The game also has stealth sections which are enjoyable however they are often repetitive and players often use the same tactics over and over (the AI in the late game does try to mix things up later), there is also a detective mode where you need to scan various crime scenes which is sadly the weakest part of the gameplay as all you do is scan an item and follow a breadcrumb trail to the next area (also the detective mode feature can be used in combat or in the stealth sections however this makes those sections a cake walk). Finally if you like collectables this game has a crap ton of them, they litter the entire map and tie into the unlock system Batman has to unlock gadgets/abilities, in the post-game you can hover them up.

Pros:
- Great Batman game!
- Great graphics, and good looking environments and characters.
- Great controls (recommend a gamepad).
- Gameplay is awesome and doesn't bore the player (some sections however are a bit tedious).
- Great story and dialogue.
- Scarecrow sections are fantastic.

Cons:
- Some bugs.
- DLC is missable just some challenge maps that can tax your abilities in combat/ Stealth arenas.
- Stealth sections are a bit on the easy side/ not challenging once you have beaten the first couple until later in the game.
- Some tedious bits in the game, also a fair amount of backtracking is involved.
- So many collectables to find (they do tie into the Batman lore though).

9/10

TL:DR: It's a great Batman game, really good single player campaign. Perfect balance of gameplay/graphics. And it has some great scriptwriting.

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Asylum (B:AA) is one of the most fantastic examples of a comic-to-video game crossover that has fans of both fully satisfied in story and gameplay. You control the Dark Knight and venture through the infamous Arkham facility using Batman's various gadgets, detective prowess and combat skills. B:AA is presented in a third-person point of view and rolls out the facility to you as a semi-open world environment. Fans of the Batman and story-driven, action-packed video games should not pass up B:AA.

reviewText: I was pretty late to the party on this one. However, five years after release this title stands as one of the greatest games I've ever played. I've always been a huge fan of Batman, but I never expected to be immersed in that world and character so intensely. The gameplay is great, the story fits perfectly into the existing Batman mythos, and the visuals stand up TO. THIS. DAY. I couldn't believe how spot on they were with even the smallest details, and how well they fleshed out the geography of the Asylum. Just when you think the game would begin to get stale they throw you a curveball, or a different style of gameplay. Whether it be Scarecrow's fear gas induced hallucinations, or a mad dash from a raging Killer Croc, I was consistently entertained and surprised throughout. And I'm not a major completionist, but I couldn't help but solve everything the Riddler threw at me throughout the game.\n\nThis game is timeless. 10/10, would Batman again.

- Some bugs.
- DLC is missable just some challenge maps that can tax your abilities in combat/ Stealth arenas.
- Stealth sections are a bit on the easy side/ not challenging once you have beaten the first couple until later in the game.
- Some tedious bits in the game, also a fair amount of backtracking is involved.
- So many collectables to find (they do tie into the Batman lore though).

9/10

TL:DR: It's a great Batman game, really good single player campaign. Perfect balance of gameplay/graphics. And it has some great scriptwriting.

reviewText: In this game you play as the one and only Batman as he takes on the Joker and his minions in Arkham Asylum. Arkham Asylum has lots of detail for a prison and you will be able to explore it as you look for the Riddler's Challenge trophies, interview tapes, and solve environmental puzzles (mostly just puns). Only complaint is that it only has 2 bosses practically. All the boss fights except for the Ivy one have you against tough Bane like inmates. I had to use it cause with my Wii controller pro because it inverted the right stick on both the X and Y axis.\n\nThe combat is really fun too and requires more timing than how it looks on video. You also get to play with toys that are sort of like Zelda items since they open up new areas. And if you like the Batman franchise you will be rewarded with your favorite villains in audio interview and the spirit of Armaedus Arkham.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best superhero games I've ever played. I've never seen a developer do such an awesome superhero game since Spider-Man 2. It's a game where you play as Batman as he tries to stop the criminals within Arkham Asylum of succeeding in their plans of killing countless people.

Why is this game so great? Well, there are a lot of reasons really. The gameplay. It's so good. Whenever I play fire this game up on my laptop and play on a challenge map, I enjoy just fighting enemies.

The combat freeflow system is amazing, you fight seamlessly from goon to goon punching them, kicking them, breaking their arm, throwing them, the combat flows so smoothly. It feels so satisfying to fight enemies with the freeflow system that Rocksteady implented. Everything connects together so well. Other than the freeflow system, the stealth is pretty satisfying when you pull it off well. The gadgets Batman uses are pretty awesome, you can set traps for enemies while you lure them in. The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is awesome, Arkham City improves on it though.

The story revolves around Batman and his usual foes as he tries to stop them from killing guards and tons of innocents. You get to fight iconic batman villains such as Scarecrow, Killer Croc, Joker, Poison Ivy and Bane.

Joker is awesome in the game, laughing maniacally as he cracks his jokes. Mark Hamill does Joker justice, his voice is perfect. Kevin Conroy also did a great job as Batman.

Get it even if you're not a Batman fan, it's amazing.

Characters: 9/10
Story: 8.5/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Sound: 8/10

Overall: 9/10

reviewText: From Bat Fan to BatmanI've played Batman Arkham Asylum to completion at least 5 times on the PS3 and to step into the shoes of the Batman, for the first time too, is a gaming experience you can't and won't forget. There are many motifs in the Batman mythos you'll be glad to notice (such as a particular constructed doorway in the fashion of the cover of A Serious House on Serious Earth, the graphic novel). The Rogues Gallery is proudly presented in interview tapes that emphasize the dark, demented world of Gotham and the voice acting is reminiscent as it is fresh every time. If you want to know what it's like to be Batman and better yet, know him, read his comics, but more importantly, play his game!

reviewText:
This review comes from an FPS-biased gamer, so it took some time (i.e. 4 years after this game launched) for me to play it, mostly because I bought it late, and partly because I was waiting for steamworks.

Now that it's supported, GFWL is gloriously gone and the steam achievements are seamless. As for the game, the intro is nice and the visuals are impressive, but I found that the game really assumes that you know what you're doing and where you're going. The map system is terrible, and I found myself doubling back down corridors over and over to figure where the heck I was supposed to be.

Half the items you see as you play the game you can't collect until after you've unlocked certain upgrades, which is frustrating, and frankly a poor way to convince a completionist to go back through all the levels he's gotten lost in and ask him to go find more trophies. Nevertheless, I did it all.

The main campaign has a solid story and - as a person who is not intimately familiar with every villian - I enjoyed reading the back stories on the characters I unlocked. The immersion level is very good, and the controls are intuitive.

Challenge mode gets a little frustrating, but it's worth it to see the achievements pop at the end.

Overall: It's a solid Batman game with some flaws, and while it doesn't stack up for me with the top games, it's still a worthy endeavor.

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best third-person stealth-action games ever made, and the best video game released by Rocksteady Studios so far. It's a fun and immersive game whether you're a DC fan or not. While the game plot is based on the comic books and not the movies, you don't need any prior experience with either to really enjoy the atmosphere created by the developers. All the action takes place on the island-bound asylum known as Arkham. Environments range from run-down morgues to a crumbling neo-gothic mansion, all of which look lush. Assisting the Joker is his army of convict henchmen who can be dispatched using vicious hand-to-hand combat moves. With no real special powers , Batman relies only on his training and gagdets. Luckily the hero can counter his enemies' close-quarter combat moves with ease, and the animation is breathtakingly fluid.

reviewText:
The Joker has taken over the Asylum and only Batman can put a stop to the madness.
I picked this up during the WB Humble Bundle where it lay unplayed in my Steam library for months, mainly due to the fact I had no way of playing it. Now that I finally have a gaming PC I decided to download and try this Dark Knight Simulator.
Now I had only ever played bits of this game on console in the past and I never really understood the hype. But after throwing all the settings on max and jumping into this game I finally saw the light (or the Dark, I guess).
Arkham Asylum comes complete with a combo/counter/beat 'em up combat system which has you throwing punches left, right and centre with the finese of a Bat. Get your combo building and the Bat becomes quicker and more powerful. But the fun doesn't end at the combat. The Joker has a night of fun in plan for the Batman and it goes from bad (by bad I mean really, really good) to worse (It starts to get really exciting towards the end.) and seeing all the familiar villians locked away in Arkham suddenly freed and hungry for the blood of the Bat leads to some utterly awesome encounters.
The Riddler also has you covered if you are looking for a game with an insane amount of collectables, the only dissapointment with this game was the lack of a New Game Plus function, although this did get rectified in the later sequels!

Fancy becoming the Bat for a night in the Joker's Funhouse? Pick this up! You know you want to.

reviewText:
Buy This:
If you enjoy 3rd person adventure games with hand to hand combat and stealth sections
If you want to REALLY feel like the Batman

I played Batman for the first time early in 2014, and absolutely loved the living crap out of it. This game does just about everything right. The atmosphere, music, story and acting are all top notch. The controls feel fluid and responsive. All I can really say to sum it all up is this game makes you feel like the Batman. There were times while swinging above my enemies, slowly dispatching them one after another I found myself giggling with a psychotic glee. Good luck finding me you brain-dead thugs! I'm  Batman!"

Arkham Asylum is a 3rd person Metroidvania styled action game. You play as Batman (of course) and explore an insane asylum that has been taken over by The Joker. You're free to explore the asylum (which is a huge island complex) at your leisure
date: but you are forced along the correct order of places by slowly unlocking new abilities.\n\nEach room in Arkham plays out like one of a few minigames depending on what's going on. Sometimes the room will be filled with armed thugs hunting you
recommended: and the game becomes a stealth game. You swing from the rafters slowly dispatching enemies that wander too far into the shadows. It is very fun. As more of the thug's friends vanish
hoursPlayed: they become more and more fearful for their own hide. By the time you're down to the last thug
voteText: they're often crying in a corner or shooting randomly all about the room screaming in absolute terror.\n\nThe game has some rooms that are filled with packs of unarmed enemies you have to beat down with your bat fists. The hand to hand combat is wildly satisfying
helpfulPercent: and soon you'll be blocking
votesHelpful: counter attacking and vaulting everything in a huge blur of bat punches.\n\nThere are still other sections that become platformers. These require you to navigate all sorts of crazy structures by jumping
votesTotal: swinging and roping all over. These aren't as strong as platforming in say
votesFunny: Prince of Persia
commentsCount: but they are decent and get the job done.\n\nThere's all sorts of other ways the game changes itself up for you as you progress
column16: but I don't want to spoil the surprise. Just do yourself a favor and go become the Batman.\n"

reviewText:
Two years ago, I watched a playthrough of this game on Youtube -- I was overseas at the time, and couldn't play the game myself. When I bought it a few months ago on Steam, I thought of maybe skipping over it and moving on to games I hadn't already seen. Damn, am I glad I didn't do that.

There's pretty much nothing I can say about Arkham Asylum that hasn't been said already. I mean, ♥♥♥♥, it came out in 2009 -- in game development terms, it's halfway to a FOSSIL. It is in the ground with sediments, you know what I mean? So let's make this quick:

Things you'll find annoying: as I've said before the Uncanny Valley is strong with this game. Although the graphics SING from most camera angles, close-ups pretty much always incite second-hand embarrassment. It feels like you're watching action figures trying to emote, and it's kind of unnerving from time to time.

The UI design is also a point of irritation. The button mapping is ♥♥♥♥ing WEIRD in this game, and totally shrugs off the industry standard for reasons that are hard to understand. Batman's utility belt is really hard to navigate, which is kind of negligible most of the time but ♥♥♥♥ing INFURIATING when you're in the heat of battle and need to switch quickly to one of your tools. Ivy ♥♥♥♥ing owned me several times thanks to this ♥♥♥♥ and definitely not because I am kind of a button-mashy litttle ♥♥♥♥ who gets really freaked out when the going gets stressful, yes, HARDY HAR HAR.

The battle system doesn't seem to know WHAT the ♥♥♥♥ it's doing. There's this huge emphasis on chaining your attacks, but the system to do so is super unintuitive, and to be honest it generally just doesn't work. Combo streaks are ruined by even a two second pause in your momentum, and it takes so long to incapacitate an enemy that's down that you're pretty much better off just staying up and wailing on them until they fall.

Also, if you're a lady, or if you're into ladies not having to deal with hypersexualization and objectification all the time... Well, let's just say this game isn't hugely progressive on that point.

Things you'll love: Pretty much everything else. Yeah, no, I'm serious. This game is ♥♥♥♥ing GREAT, it's awesome. DCAU Batman is my ♥♥♥♥ing jam, dude. Seriously, here is a list of everything Arkham Asylum does SO RIGHT:

*  The voice acting. Kevin Conroy as Batman? Mark Hamill as Joker?? Arleen Sorkin as Harley Quinn??? Jesus take the wheel.
*  The narrative. Utilizing the freeroam features as well as certain linear segments, Arkham Asylum feels rich and multidimensional, and successfully brings you fully along with its main character. Being Bruce feels good, it feels powerful and awesome, and your compulsion as a player to pursue his nemesis to the end of the game is very organic and real. The story is interesting and fun to play, and very well-paced.
*  The fan service. The amount of available fan service -- from hidden easter eggs to second-long cameos -- makes this game highly accessible both to longtime Batman fans, and to brand new ones. Even though I've been a big fan of Batman for a long time, I found myself learning things I'd never known before about some of my favorite Batman characters.
*  The gameplay. Although the combat and UI are set up in a way that sort of annoys me, the gameplay is KILLER nonetheless. The stealth sections allow for a high level of creativity and invention; the combat-heavy sections allow you to feel like a completely, heavy metal bad ♥♥♥; the bosses each demand your creativity and engagement in a different way, and all of them are REALLY cool.

This game is ROCKIN and you will enjoy playing it if you enjoy fun. Period.

(But... c'mon. You knew that.)

reviewText: This... is easily one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. This game is good. No, this game is downright amazing. Why is it so good? Everything about this game is why. Not a single feature was made poorly. The asylum looks amazing, it almost even has a feel to it like you are actually there. Every single little detail on every thing is very well made. And then there is the story. It's like they took a page out of the Animated Batman series and made a movie based on it, but as a game. It is really well written. And the acting, my god the acting. I can't even begin to describe it, just play it already. The gameplay is also really well made to. There are essentially three aspects to the game. The first is the combat. At first it just seems like you could just mash the attack button but as the game goes on it introduces so many features. Mainly there is a combo system where you have to only hit the button once between hits to keep it going. You want to keep it going so you can use the really good moves that you unlock. Also there are enemies that have to be hit in certain ways or you get hurt. The other aspect is stealth. It's pretty straight forward and that is what works about it. You don't have much to worry about other than staying out of line of sight while picking off the guards one by one. There are also gadgets to use that can let you do some pretty cool things. The third aspect is exploring the island. While the game is pretty much linear there is a bit of a puzzle for how to get to the next area or actual puzzle like sections and even some hidden goodies. Definitely one of the games where it is worth getting all the collectibles in.\n\nI give the game 5 batarangs out of 5.

reviewText:
Nanananananana batmens !!!

Speli iegadajos jo humbebundle bija akcija un spelei bija loti labs metescore (91). Sakuma domaju ka var but tik labs? Bet kad saku spelet sapratu.  ievads taka bija pa ilgu. Un tad jokers izmuk un sakas terors arkham island.Speles turpinas un ari turpinasies ar banditu sisanu.nosakuma tas skita neinterasnti bet kad sakas upgrade un kombo taisisana aiziet liela azarta.Un tad paradijas riddlera miklas kas man pasam bija viss interesantaka lieta, bet kas ari aiznema speles ilgako dalu.Man patika ka vini betmenu nenosauca par supervaroni bet gan par pasaules labako dektektivu un kas skita pa visam logiski.Speles laika tu iegust visadas papildmantinas un kuras tu uzlabo.Speles minusus uz reiz redzeju jo es tads malacis saku nu ar arkham city. Protams tie bija svarigas lietas ka: lidosanas laika nomerket un izsaut uz vietu kur velies.Saja spelet bija vel leksanas poga(spelejot arkham city tu doma kpc nav),bet izradijas pa tiesam lieka spelejot.Spelet pec iziesana pagarinas ar riddlera miklam kas liek padomat bet saja dala tas ir atri izpildamas.(ja tev vel ir karte).Par atminejumiem to iegusti citu cilveku biografiju un vel 3d telus vari apskatit.Spele vel ir chalange mods kurs ir neliels, bet grutaks neka arkham city. Ir 2 veidi sado visiem pa seju ar lielaku kombo vai ari sado konkreta veida cilvekiem pa mapi ejot abos gadijumos ir ieteicams dabut visus upgrade citadi bus gruti vai nevaresi iziet.upgrade klasts bija loti normala daudzuma.Spele man skita aizraujosa ari tas ka bija bosu rezims.Spele man ilga tikai ap12h izejot SP un ari ridlera miklas visas. Bet vel nav iziets challange mods ta ka es to citigi daru.So spele iesaku visiem un loti rekomendeju nopirkt visas 3 dala.

Mans vertejums 9.1/10

reviewText: Batman: Arkham Asylum is the first batman game I have played of the series, despite the fact that it is the first published. I finished Arkham Origins before this, which improved gameplay for me a bit more, as I started this but never got around to finishing it till not too long ago. In summary, this is a good game. You should get this game, but its not all that hard, which is a problem, though, still a heavy recommendation.

reviewText:
There are no real words to describe this.
This game is beyond amazing, it's terrifying, mysterious, puzzling and has a finger biting plotline.
Let me review every aspect.
Plot: Extremely great, I love the transition between enemies and how this and that happens.
Graphics: For it's time, it's really well done.
Characters (Im gonna make this subparted.)
Batman: He's what he is, in the comics, movies, and the cartoons. A dark, mysterious, yet lonely character.
Joker: Nothing new, but nothing bad either. The voice acting is great and his involvement in the plot is well, unexpected at least.
Scarecrow: One of my favorite enemies, I love this scarecrow, he's what I expected plus more! He's crazy and terrifying and he reveals a bit of Batman's fears.
Bane: Appears during 2 scenes and one boss fight. Great Bane and how he well, is in general.
Poison Ivy: Drop-dead gorgeous, Ivy is a cool enemy and brings well a bunch more ♥♥♥♥ to the Arkham Asylum facilities.
Croc: Great, he wasnt hard per se, but getting in and out was difficult and terrifying.
Riddler: He didnt make a physical appearance in the game but he does speak every time you pick up a trophy or solve a puzzle.
And last.. Harley (Im not going to include Zsasz) She's ravishing and crazy and well, not much to say.
This is one of the few games that even when I get frustrated I always come back to play it.
10/10.

reviewText:
Here is my review for Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition

Intro:   The story places after Batman has finally captured Joker and is transporting him to Arkham Asylum. He senses something bigger is happening, but isn't sure what it is. After entering Arkham Asylum, Batman becomes just another inmate and must battle his enemies and restore order the Asylum.

Gameplay / Sound:   Batman AA plays like a super advanced version of crackdown. Don't know crackdown? Well its a action adventure game where you use buttons to chain together attacks and combine with Batman's arsenal. It involves kicks, batarangs, batman's cape, explosive gel and many other items. While in combat you can chain these weapons along with dodge and counter button to quickly wipe out the enemy. The second part is part stealth action game, where you can take down enemies without alerting anyone, in classic Batman fashion. There is great satisifaction from taking on 6-10 enemies and just picking them all off, one by one. The only issue I have with this is that you have to watch slow mo" kills on the last enemy. Granted you can skip it
date: it almost doesnt feel really necessary to also cut to that. All the inmates are like mini hulks and just look like the can bash your skull in
recommended: luckily Batman is a master of combat.  After about the first couple of hours the combat begins to grow stale and repetitive. If you complete 100 % everything like I do
hoursPlayed: than it almost becomes a grind. Other than that a normal playthrough will be enough for most players. The sound effects whether you are solving riddler challenges or destroying Joker's toy teeth
voteText: each sound is unique that you'll always remember what each sound indicates. The voices of fan favorites shows up in Batman AA and makes the game very nostalgic.\n\nStory :   The story of Arkham Asylum revolves around Batman trying to escape from AA and stop the Joker from unleashing a weapon upon Gotham. The story is fleshed out between common knowledge
helpfulPercent: background audio tapes dubbed "patient reports" and through dialogue. In terms of complete story Batman AA has it all. A clear Beginning
votesHelpful: Middle and End. You never are lost and are always free to continue the main story whenever. This means going on "side quests" to collect all the goodies hidden in the asylum. The story mainly focuses on Joker and Batman
votesTotal: but many other villains show up to help move the plot along. The story is almost purely confinded to the island
votesFunny: whether it is above or below
commentsCount: you grow to love the asylum
column16: no matter how many enemies reside within its walls.\n\nReplayability:   Batman AA has tons of replayability for players who are looking to collect all the achievements
column17: records
column18: and solve the riddlers questions. Outside of all those things
column19: there isn't any main story to complete after you run through it. Extra modes like the fighting
column20: stealth and reward challenges will keep you busy
column21:
but after that the replay value decreases. Batman AA is meant for a story playthrough and includes all these extras to keep you interested. Most people will just complete the story and will be satisfied with their time on Arkham Asylum.

Controls:  The controls are fluid and really smooth. Rocksteady worked hard on this and makes it very easy for anyone to pick and a play. There is no big learning curve which makes this a very attractive game to new users and veteran players.

Conclusion: If you are looking into buying Arkham Asylum or a Batman fan
column22: this is the game for you. It has tons of juicy story content
column24: and a great open world system. The combat can get reptitive and some tasks might repeat themselves
column25: but overall Batman Arkham Asylum is a great addition to everyone's collection.\n\nFinal Score: 9 out of 10"

reviewText:
I'm not a big fan of Batman, having never read the comics or even seen all of the big new films.
However, I enjoyed this game a lot.

It's a solid adventure game set in an island prison.
Iconic Batman villains have all made their way there and are running loose until you go punch them in the face.
It has its rough edges here and there, but honestly, I had a great time with this.

My main gripe, one that had me stumped for a good long while, was the 'investigate' mechanic.
This is mapped to holding the left bumper (or whatever keyboard button switches on detective mode). Investigating things in the game is explained once at the very start, then used for optional collectibles and backstory, then suddenly, well past the halfway point, makes its return critical to the game's progress.
I'd by then completely forgotten how to trigger this and the game doesn't re-explain the mechanic or even list it in the controls or help functions. I eventually had to dig through guides and walkthroughs for a refresher on how this core game mechanic worked.

The rest of the game is totally fine though.
Batman and its universe will always be a bit silly in a totally straight-faced way, but this outing definitely showed that it can be presented in a way enjoyable to non-fans as well.

reviewText:
COMPLETED 100%


A fine game, typical of Unreal Engine 3 structure, that is flawless in design and gameplay. The fighting mechanics is amazingly fluid and smooth and it's simple for Batman to easily leap around to enemies, even those far away from him, with the press of a button. Game is technically open world; small in size but non-linear with different distinct separate areas to explore. Can't find anything bad to say about the game but it's easy to see why it's rated so highly.
IMO The Amazing Spiderman game is better than this though.

reviewText:
Either if you are fan of Batman or not, I think this game is worth playing.

Game is linear/semi-open world - You can sometimes choose which route to go, or what to do, but on other hand, the game always guides you through different mechanics that you will easy understand that you are on the right track.

Story is simple but engaging and it sets an interesting mood during the whole game. That being said, atmosphere is amazing, it can change from funny jokes from The Joker to scary sewers where Killer Croc lives.

For people unfamiliar with Batman lore this game does a really good job about explaining different characters from the Gotham City trough tapes or riddles.

The Riddler (Edward Nigma) has interesting part in the game. He has hidden many different riddles and trophies around the island for you to find. Advice: Don't sweat over some riddles as they are solvable only later in game when you have more gadgets.

++ Story
++ Atmosphere
++ Riddles
++ Character bios

-- Quite short - if you rush it, you can finish the story within few hours
-- Small world - you will visit the same areas over and over again
-- Five types of enemies
-- Easy boss fights

reviewText:
I was late to the table where this franchise is concerned. I played Batman; Arhkam City nearly two years after its release, and needless to say I was hooked. I wasn't willing to buy a PS3 or Xbox 360 for one game, and I didn't have a PC capable of handling the game, so I had to wait for a while before I got around to this title.

As the title may suggest, Batman; Arkham Asylum (BAA) is a fascinating romp through Gotham's infamous Arkham Asylum. The battle interface used throughout the series makes a very strong debut as you fight hordes of crazed criminals while attempting to regain control of the facility from the Joker. There are several memorable encounters with other well-known characters from the Batman universe along the way. The game very successfully gives the player an opportunity to be the Batman in a variety of situations. One moment you will need to stealthily overtake an area by sneaking through vents and hanging from gargoyles to secure a room full of armed baddies. The next you may be in an all-out brawl with a grundle of thugs. At other times you will use your investigative skills to locate evidence to help you along the way. It is all well done and such a blast! I highly recommend this title to anyone who enjoys a well made game.

10/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Most superhero games aren’t very good. But Arkham Asylum changed that. It made people say, ‘Finally! A superhero game that doesn’t suck!’ Batman Arkham Asylum is about Batman (duh) getting trapped in Arkham Asylum (also duh). Unfortunately he is trapped with some of the most dangerous criminals in all of Gotham, including the Joker, Killer Croc, Poison Ivy and Scarecrow.
The game controls aren’t too hard to figure out. You use the mouse to look around and to attack and block. Space to run, and ctrl to crouch. Every time you knock down a thug you get experience points. Get enough of them and you can level up. Levelling up allows you to pick an upgrade, such as armour improvements and new abilities. Obviously you can’t have a Batman game without gadgets, so throughout the game you will unlock many, including batarangs, grapple gun, and oh, did I mention explosives?
The Boss fights/Areas are quite varied, from overcoming Scarecrows fear gas, to sneaking through the sewers trying not to be eaten by Killer Croc. Although one problem I had with the game was the fact that Bane wasn’t smart. Instead all he does is through things at you and ram you. But that’s pretty much my only problem with the game.
If this game was a spoon, it would a good spoon.
I’m giving this game spoon/10

reviewText:
Man this game. Where do I begin?

The atmosphere just gets you right in the gut from the beginning of the game. Filling you inside this disturbed and twisted asylum filled with the beloved Batman characters we all know today. It's pretty damn good for just the beginning of the game. It starts already with you capturing Joker, which is a change in pace of the typical Batman stuff we know. However it has, dare I say, realism aspects in the game. This changes the overall mood and pace; this game wants you to take it seriously and they convey a good job of that.

The controls are tight and compact. I rarely have issues with them other than some hiccups here and there, but it's rare. It feels very comfortable and smooth, where even the most basic of games like Left 4 Dead have some problems with gamepad support, dispite the limitations. I was playing with a gamepad this run, so the keyboard and mouse may have more polished controls than the standard, though I digress.

The characters have, duh, character. The basic batman shows and comics have the same idea, though this game makes it all well and good. I was wondering what character would act like what, and it just left me guessing over and over.

My favorite part was the scarecrow sequences. It was just plain brilliant. It had some scare factor, and a level of difficulty to the game. It breaks the action from the typical game and throws you for a loop each sequence: even going as far to break the 4th wall entirely.

The ending, however wasn't very polished. For the sake of people wanting to know themselves, I won't spoil this. Though I admit it could be done a little better.

Overall, give this game your money. I mean it. It deserves it. And it deserved Game of the Year. Get it. Now.

reviewText:
Great game with beautiful atmospheric graphics.  The voice acting is way above par and the storyline is as good as any comic based game or movie can possibly offer.  There's extra side challenges you can do to extend the length of the game such as collecting riddles or finding interviews of the inmates, but overall looks like the game shouldn't take much longer than 10 hours to beat if you play it straight through.

The animation is very smooth and fluid and the action makes you really feel like you're kicking some ♥♥♥.  Some may find this a little too streamlined, but upgrade the difficulty level and you'll learn quick that you can have full control of the action rather than button mashing to win the fight.

Good mixture of stealth/action, puzzles, and adventure.

Great game!

I'd by then completely forgotten how to trigger this and the game doesn't re-explain the mechanic or even list it in the controls or help functions. I eventually had to dig through guides and walkthroughs for a refresher on how this core game mechanic worked.

The rest of the game is totally fine though.
Batman and its universe will always be a bit silly in a totally straight-faced way, but this outing definitely showed that it can be presented in a way enjoyable to non-fans as well.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is a pioneer which changed the landscape of superhero genre in the gaming industry.

Story is well written, as you will feel tension in the atmosphere. Joker pulls all the strings and you must fight the odds. It starts off with Joke being escorted to his asylum under Batman and Arkham Asylum's watchful eyes but Joker manages to escape and turns the asylum into his playground. You must save the people in the asylum and stop this madness that Joker had planned all along. The voice acting is top-notch. One can listen to Joker or the Riddler talk all day. The Scarecrow bit in the game is one of the best gaming moments ever. I loved the tone of many super-villians in an asylum with Batman. This game changed the whole landscape for the superhero games.

You will feel like Batman as you will owerpower most of the thugs. Different gadgets are used to solve puzzles and move ahead in the story. The sleath mechanics are well done too and one of the best parts about stealth is how after you take out one of the enemies the fear slowly grips other enemies as they become aggressive but as soon as the numbers start dwindlling they start to panic, this machenic is one of the best in the gaming history. Boss fights on the other hand were a bit too easy and lackluster. Also there is some odd detective work which was nice. Of course, there is the good old fashioned brawling there too.

Graphics and atmosphere are good as they capture the tone of the dark and gritty world. Art-style is also very good. Environmental design is brilliant and there a twisted sense of character in every area you’ll discover. This claustrophobic cove of madness oozing terror has to be one of the best settings in video-games.

It has everything you would like from an immersive world, great storyline, sleath, detective work and old fashioned brawling. What else do you want? So, are you a Batman fan? buy this game, even if you are not one you will still love this game and is inarguably one of the best superhero games ever.

reviewText:
For those who don’t already know about this treasure I only discovered and played recently Batman: Arkham Asylum is an excellent story action/stealth action game, any Batman or DC fan would love.

Pros; Nice fighting mechanics (I played Mad Max before this and read many reviews about how the fighting style was similar this is just as good with sometimes better visuals when you unlock the moves), you will take on small to large groups of enemies in a smack/counter moves. For those who enjoy Stealth based games this has plenty, I’m not a big fan of this genre but was pleasantly surprised it didn’t take over and was easy to get into and perform those silent take downs without being seen. Some nice boss/villain fights to keep you entertained. A few minor puzzles and collectables in the form of Riddler riddles, some of which require you to grapple, climb or just scan areas in far off corners. Excellent story as mentioned before as Batman battles an array of villains as well as a nice steady progress as the henchmen themselves get harder to defeat.

Cons; Personally the only thing that slightly annoyed me was the Scarecrow sections as the game seemed to switch from 3D to a strange 2D style, this also occurred in a few fights towards the end. Not a big issue but did confuse me as the normal game view and ability to move the camera were just fine.

Overall and excellent game that holds up to many even to this date well worth is asking price even more so if on sale, thumbs up!

reviewText:
It's hard to find any flaws in Arkham Asylum.  It's a solid action/adventure game that is very successful in making the player feel like they are Batman.  This is something just about every Batman game released before Arkham Asylum failed to do.  It manages to achieve this through a perfect combat system that allows you to utilise gadgets while throwing enemies around.  I couldn't find any faults in the control system or combat mechanics.

The game offers fantastic voice acting, great graphics, enjoyable story, an upgrade system that flows well with the story, the combination of puzzle and stealth elements.  Then when you are finished with the story, you can spend time collecting trophies within the game.  Collecting these trophies never even felt like a chore.  You can then test your combat skills in the challenge section, as well as your stealth instincts in the predator challenge section.

You have plenty to discover in the game, with many villains making appearances, full bios, hidden recordings, riddler trophies and many hidden areas within the map.  If you combine everything I have mentioned, you have an unforgettable experience and a game that is quite possible (at the time of writing) the best comic game ever made.

reviewText:
If you haven't picked up Batman: Arkham Asylum, you're a crazy person. The game came out about a year ago and I declared that it was the best comic book game of all time. What's your deal? Get it. However, if you ignored me, Batman: Arkham Asylum (Game of the Year Edition) has come along and it's a worthy addition to your videogame collection.

Batman GOTY is the original game I loved along with four additional challenge maps and the newfound ability to play in 3D. Basically, it's more bang for your buck.

Now, before visions of Avatar-like 3D go running through your head, it's important to point out that the 3D in Batman GOTY is super-basic. You turn on the 3D filter from the main menu, pop on a pair of paper glasses with pink and green lenses, and play. It works – the HUD is at the forefront and there's definitely a depth of field effect – but it's not amazing and the glasses wash the color out of the game. That sucks seeing as how the environments and action look so good in Arkham Asylum.
The challenge maps are cool. Crime Alley is a fist-fighting challenge where you need to beat four waves of the Joker's men, and it's set in the very alley where Bruce Wayne's parents were killed. Nocturnal Hunter is a silent challenge where you need to take out a bunch of guards and complete some objectives. Meanwhile, Totally Insane and Scarecrow Nightmare throw enemies at you until you fall. All are fun and welcome additions to the regular game's challenges.

If you haven't picked up this game, you should have no qualms about grabbing Batman: Arkham Asylum (Game of the Year). If you already own Batman, the 3D and challenge maps (a few of which you can just download) really don't warrant you plunking down your pocket change to buy this one again.
Batman: Arkham Asylum is a third-person action game casting you as -- you guessed it, chum -- the Dark Knight himself. The title opens with Batman racing back to Arkham, Gotham's home for the criminally insane, with the Joker in tow. Seems the Clown Prince of Crime broke out a few weeks ago, but Batman was able to track him down and re-apprehend the baddie. However, things are never what they seem with the Joker, so after getting the wiry maniac back into the building -- a building stocked with hundreds of the Joker's goons after a mysterious" fire at their prison -- Mr. J breaks free with the help of Harley Quinn

reviewText:
I'm not one for superhero games, in fact, I don't really care much for superheroes in general. I'm a hipster, I like Spawn! But that's beside the point. Batman Arkham Asylum is beat-em'-up kind of game that moreso tests your reaction timing and ability to adapt moreso than actually beating up the enemies compared to Bayonetta or Devil May Cry.
The music is a little on the bland side, its pretty generic.

PROS
- Arkham Asylum stands out as a game with a simple and easy combat system, terrific voice acting, a decent story, and level design (that more or less infuriates me in how confusing it is sometimes).
- Excellent character portrayal, Joker is meant to be crazy while Batman is a brooding intellectual type, and boy, did they nailed it. If you're a big fan of the Batman universe, then you're definitely in for a treat. I'm not, but I still enjoyed it.
- A small island with a giant ♥♥♥ and needlessly complicated facility  to explore, there's not much to explore, but its there. To, uh, you know, explore.
- The Arkham series is the best game to try and make you feel like the Batman, and it does a pretty good job at doing that.

CONS
- Puzzles! Puzzles! Depending if you love 'em or hate 'em, its pretty well done here. Except the Riddler, that's kind of more annoying and tedious than anything else. The Riddler's riddles are well done, but the trophy collecting...ugh, remove that and I'd slap this as a pro.
- Joker gets caught by Batman, Batman puts Joker in prison, Joker has a plan to break out, Batman screwed up, Joker is free,  Batman tries to stop Joker. This is your typical Batman vs Joker relationship that has been going for decades. Its nothing new, its just normal at this point and it'll never change. Mainly because Batman is against killing people.
- For the Batman, you aren't very equipped at the very start to tackle much of anything, its a little sad, considering Batman is supposed to always come prepared for any kind of situations. I'm aware its more for not overwhelming the player all at once, but when its necessary to have those gadget upgrades to go back and hunt Riddler trophies, backtracking becomes a chore to scavenger hunt for those.

A very good game that withstood the test of time, most games created during the seventrh generation looks very bad when you go back to it, but not this one! No sir, this game is definitely a good pickup, even if you're not a Batman fan like me.

reviewText:
I'm not one for superhero games, in fact, I don't really care much for superheroes in general. I'm a hipster, I like Spawn! But that's beside the point. Batman Arkham Asylum is beat-em'-up kind of game that moreso tests your reaction timing and ability to adapt moreso than actually beating up the enemies compared to Bayonetta or Devil May Cry.
The music is a little on the bland side, its pretty generic.

PROS
- Arkham Asylum stands out as a game with a simple and easy combat system, terrific voice acting, a decent story, and level design (that more or less infuriates me in how confusing it is sometimes).
- Excellent character portrayal, Joker is meant to be crazy while Batman is a brooding intellectual type, and boy, did they nailed it. If you're a big fan of the Batman universe, then you're definitely in for a treat. I'm not, but I still enjoyed it.
- A small island with a giant ♥♥♥ and needlessly complicated facility  to explore, there's not much to explore, but its there. To, uh, you know, explore.
- The Arkham series is the best game to try and make you feel like the Batman, and it does a pretty good job at doing that.

CONS
- Puzzles! Puzzles! Depending if you love 'em or hate 'em, its pretty well done here. Except the Riddler, that's kind of more annoying and tedious than anything else. The Riddler's riddles are well done, but the trophy collecting...ugh, remove that and I'd slap this as a pro.
- Joker gets caught by Batman, Batman puts Joker in prison, Joker has a plan to break out, Batman screwed up, Joker is free,  Batman tries to stop Joker. This is your typical Batman vs Joker relationship that has been going for decades. Its nothing new, its just normal at this point and it'll never change. Mainly because Batman is against killing people.
- For the Batman, you aren't very equipped at the very start to tackle much of anything, its a little sad, considering Batman is supposed to always come prepared for any kind of situations. I'm aware its more for not overwhelming the player all at once, but when its necessary to have those gadget upgrades to go back and hunt Riddler trophies, backtracking becomes a chore to scavenger hunt for those.

A very good game that withstood the test of time, most games created during the seventrh generation looks very bad when you go back to it, but not this one! No sir, this game is definitely a good pickup, even if you're not a Batman fan like me.

reviewText: 아캄버스 시리즈의 시작을 알리는 기념비적인 어사일럼. 수없이 나왔다 소리도 없이 사라지는 히어로게임들중에 최고라 칭할수있는 시리즈의 시작이다. 빌런과 배트맨의 캐릭터성을 너무나도 잘살린 여러가지 연출과 초보자들에게도 쉽게 다가갈수있는 전투방식. 잡입게임으로도 플레이가 가능할정도의 맵디자인 패드사용시 알게돼는 너무나도 뛰어난 타격감. GOTY라는 타이틀이 전혀 어색하지가 않다. 최고 단점으로는 연출에만 집중한듯한 힘빠지는 보스전. 그 구성과 여러가지 캐릭터성은 잘살린듯하지만 자세히 보면 그저 평소 전투의 연속된 측면이 많다. 리들러 챌린지는 도전과제를 달성한다는 재미와 아캄버스의 세계관을 좀더 잘알수있게 해주는 측면도 있지만. 누군가에게는 그저 안해도 그만인 숨은 트로피 찾기가 된다. 어찌보면 양날의 검같은 시스템. 여러가지로 많은 재미를 안겨주었지만 2회차 플레이의 동기화를 못찾게 해주고. 리들러챌린지의 반만큼만 사이드 미션이 있다면 어쨌을까라는 아쉬움도 많이 남는다. 너무나도 괜찮은 작품이기에 그만큼 사소한것도 아쉬워지는 작품이다.

reviewText:
Well it´s been a while since we enjoyed a good Batman game  OST HARDLY RELATED  but this game is quite interesting...


Rocksteady Studios brought us this game in 2009, thats 3 years after Urban Chaos their first game (which was quite good IMO) so i´ve been waiting the Goty Edition of this game for a while and it´s time to talk.

It uses the Unreal Engine 3, built by the awarded Studio Epic Games, and it uses very well the LCPP (Lightning Calculations Per Pixel) and the HDRR (High Dynamic Range Renderer) allows you to behold all the scenery created for the game.

The plot is awesome, a twisted Joker instigate an elaborate plan to gain the control of Arkham Asylum, trapping Batman inside with all the maniacs and foes that he has been imprisioning all these years. As you see it´s simple but full of shades among the different corridors of the Asylum. During the game you´ll find some of the most famous villains, and every boss fight hides messages as references for their comic-story.


As for the gameplay. Actually its fun, it has some fails of course but you can still enjoy the combat. You can counter, attack or stun your enemy with the Freeflow combat, this system also allows Batman to move fast between your targets, chaining different combos with your gadgets in order to get over with.
If you don´t want to fight all day you can use predatory tactics. The predator combat is based on the stealth, silent knockbacks, takedowns, drops or even using your gadgets (like explosives) to destroy walls or roofs in order to tilt the odds in your favor.
After this you´ll be rewarded with XP, which are used to:

-Improve your physicall armor.
-Unlock combat moves & Gadgets.
-Get Health upgrades.

What about the enemies? Well, they react to your own acts as Batman. If they find inconcious allies their fear" will raise

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is a 2009 action-adventure video game based on the DC Comics superhero Batman. It was developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Eidos Interactive in conjunction with Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 video game consoles, and Microsoft Windows. It was released worldwide for consoles, beginning in North America on August 25, 2009, with a Microsoft Windows version following on September 15.

Written by veteran Batman writer Paul Dini, Arkham Asylum is based on the long-running comic book mythos. In the game's main storyline, Batman's archenemy, the Joker, instigates an elaborate plot to seize control of Arkham Asylum and trap Batman inside with many of his incarcerated foes. With Joker threatening to detonate hidden bombs around fictional Gotham City, Batman is forced to fight his way through the asylum's inmates and put an end to the Joker's plans. Most of the game's leading characters are voiced by actors who have appeared in other media based on the DC Animated Universe; Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Arleen Sorkin reprised their roles as Batman, the Joker, and his sidekick Harley Quinn respectively. The game is presented from the third-person perspective with a primary focus on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets that can be used in combat and exploration.

The game received critical acclaim—particularly for its narrative—and won several awards, including Best Action Adventure game, Best Game, and Game of the Year from different media outlets. It held the Guinness World Record for Most Critically Acclaimed Superhero Game Ever". A Game of the Year edition was released on March 26
recommended: and an OS X version was released in November 2011. Arkham Asylum '​s success launched a series of Batman: Arkham sequels
hoursPlayed: beginning in October 2011 with Batman: Arkham City."

Игра класирана в Книгата на рекордите на Гинес в номинация игра за супергерои и получи най-висок рейтинг в историята на компютърните игри. Екип от разработчици от Rocksteady Studios управляваните успя да направи една игра, която е добре приета, дори и тези, които в действителност не са фенове на Батман - преди това играта не може да се похвали с такъв успех и популярност. Rocksteady първоначално се приближи този проект с акцент върху качеството, с особено внимание и грижа, като се вземат предвид всички малки детайли и подробности Девет години история на комикси и адаптации на Батман, и по този начин се създаде ново ниво на качество в областта на компютърните игри. В Arkham Asylum ние сме свидетели на един доста брутален Батман, тактичен, разумно хищен и наистина мрачна ситуация. Тъй като това допринася за доброто съвпадение звуков компонент. В играта има отлична система за борба, има елементи на стелт, изкуствени опоненти и разузнаване в режим на хищник е доста добър. Решавам пъзели на Гатанката, много забавна игра. В играта има своя собствена индивидуалност, целостта на сюжета и неговата доставка. Игра на 2009 г., която ще надмине много съвременни занаяти.\nRocksteady поставила за цел, да направи най-добрата игра на всички видео игри на Батман и те успяха.\nШедьовър! 10 от 10.

reviewText:

So I always heard good things about the Batman Arkham games, but never got to play them. Last week I installed and played the copy of Batman: Arkham Asylum I had lying on my endlessly growing Steam backlog for the first time. After 30 hours of gametime, which included beating the campaign on both normal and hard difficulty, collecting all of the Riddler challenges, getting 3 stars on all the extra challenge mode games, and acquiring all of the achievements, I can confidently say that B: AA is one of the best games I ever played in a long time.

I just want to preface the upcoming gushing I'm about to lay down by saying I love metroidvanias, am not very proficient in high execution gameplay, enjoy a good collect-a-thon, and think Batman is the ♥♥♥♥. This game pushed so many of the right buttons for me as a result.

The best description I can give for the gameplay is that it’s the perfect Batman experience. You can do most of the typical kind of platforming tricks you see in modern 3D action adventure games like in the Assassin Creed games but as Batman you have a variety of tools like a grappling hook that clings on almost all climbable ledges and a cape that helps you glide over larges distances. I found going around the titular asylum a very enjoyable experience, especially the occasional pure platforming and Scarecrow sections you’re encounter throughout the campaign.

The combat is probably the best part of the game. It really feels like you’re playing out a fight scene in a Batman cartoon or movie. It’s very simple to jump around the area pummeling your foes but you need proper timing and twitchy fingers to avoid getting hit and keeping your combo score up. You get a lot of tools and techniques that make the combat a breeze later on but I found myself being tested in some hard mode gauntlets and the dedicated challenge modes you unlock later in the game. Climbing on the larger titan enemies and forcing them to smack around the smaller goons is always a satisfying experience.

The predator sections where you have to stealthily take out a bunch of armed enemies in a huge room is fun. Pure fun. There are so many ways to dispatch them that they made a dedicated game mode for it. And the way the goons start getting freaked out after you pick them off is hilarious as ♥♥♥♥. Like I said, a very Batman-like experience.

While the campaign is pretty linear, there are a ton of collectables sprinkled throughout the island. In a way this game is pretty metroidvana-like in that aspect, as you can backtrack to older areas and use the new items you acquire as you progress through the game to find even more secrets.  While the trophy collecting was pretty basic, the riddles sprinkled throughout the world are brilliant. I got a kick out of finding all of the solutions. You’ll also find these little perspective puzzles that require you to find 2 parts of a question mark hidden on the architecture and align them with your camera so they look whole. It’s hard to explain but they were cool.

The game is a visual and audible treat. The game looks very good, especially for an early-to-mid last gen game. I love all the minute detail for the world, like how Batman gets more visually damaged and grows a stubble as the campaign goes on. All the classic Batman characters get a gritty look that makes them look pretty badass (even though Batman still is wearing his underwear on the outside).  Getting some of the voices from the old animated series was pretty cool. Can’t say no to Steve Blum either.

/gush

Now, I do have some gripes with the game, though. You more and less fight the same kinds of goons throughout the game. The boss fights aren’t very good either, especially the final boss fight. Spoiler: I don’t like that you’re basically have a generic video game-like fight with a huge monster version of the Joker instead of an elaborate battle of wits that you see in other Batman works. It just felt out of place is all.

Anyway, I love this game and I am so looking forward to playing Batman Arkham games in the future.
A really fun game.  Makes you feel like Batman.  You get to use a lot of Batman's gadgets.  A lot of the classic Batman villains appear in the game.  The controls and the fighting system feel solid.

The best of the Batman games so far. Amazing story, atmosphere, game mechanics.... it really doesn't get much better than this.

This is where it all began - one of the best action games I've come to play, and still perhaps my most favored of the Batman trilogy. It's not as big or as long as the Arkham City or the Origins, but it feels complete, which its successors failed to accomplish - at least in my opinion.

The game is very loyal to the comic books and anyone familiar with Frank Miller's Batman stories - Batman: Year One and Dark Knight Returns - should find themselves right at home with this game. The voice actors have done a superb job with their roles and I can't praise Mark Hamill enough for his role as the Joker; the man is simply amazing - hard to believe the same voice belongs to Luke Skywalker. Graphically the game has aged well, and I still find myself impressed with what they've done with the environments and the characters themselves, and let us not forget the music - it has a very Tim Burton's Batman type of sound and enhances the experience even further.

So yes, I'd say this is a must buy to anyone who considers themselves a Batman fan.

Bottom line: 5 years after release and this is still an Awesome game. Some slowdown during one of the three Scarecrow sections but all in all, fantastic.\n\nIf you have not played the Best Batman game ever, well, what are you waiting for?

The storyline is fantastic, the characters are taken straight out of the comic universe so of course that is fantastic, and most importantly, the gameplay is fantastic. Even though it feels like the combat would get repetitive, it just doesn't because there is a perfect blend of environment variety and equiptment pacing. Almost every little thing you can think of feels like it was placed there for a specific game design reason, whether it be the guards standing position, or a little cupboard to hide behind. You generally cycle through different types of gameplay, from brawling, to stealth, to platforming, to pure epic boss fights.\n\nI particularly love the encounters with the scarecrow because it really shakes up the gameplay with a completely different camera perspective, and a branched off story about bruce wayne's past. While I usually have too much anxiety to play games with dark settings (like bioshock or deadspace), the game really makes me feel like I am batman and am the hunter not the hunted. I cannot reccomend this game more.
MASTERPIECE 10/11

Batman: Arkham Asylum might very well be the first great Batman game. Although there's been plenty of Batman games in the past, I think this one perfectly captures the essence of the Dark Knight. Set in Gotham's famous asylum, you'll find yourself fighting against Batman's greatest rival: the Joker himself, as he attempts to pull out one of his greatest plans.

The fact that this takes place in the asylum, means that the Joker will not be the only member of Batman's rogues gallery you'll be encountering. Harley Quinn, Killer Croc, Poison Ivy, to name a few. Not to mention that the asylum is filled not only with Joker's henchment, but you'll also run into a few of the crazier inmates as well. Finally, the place itself really makes you feel that you're in Arkham, and it adds a sense of isolation.

As far as gameplay goes, you're the Dark Knight. You'll spend a lot of time either beating up several thugs at once, or scaring the heck out of them as you take them out one by one in the predator rooms without being noticed. All of this can be accomplished with the help of Batman's arsenal of gadgets, from the classic Batarangs, to explosive gel. Then there's also Detective Mode, which allows you to scout the area to detect enemies and possible ways to take them down.

It's a really good game; I recommend it.

Batman: Arkham Asylum was the best action game of 2009.  I originally played this game on Xbox 360, but revisited the PC version and enjoyed it again even more with crisper graphics.  While the game does have some beat 'em up elements to it, it won't tire you out on them.  Though, if you do enjoy them, like I did, the game offers a challenge mode that lets you enjoy the wonderful contextual combo system.

Much of the appeal is the puzzle-like approach to clearing a room, or getting to your next objective by sticking to the shadows and using the fear tactics that Batman is known for.  The story is compelling, and the gameplay offers just enough variety to keep it from feeling bland.  There is a pleasant mixture of brawling, stealth action, story sequences, and detective work to keep your attention.

If you haven't yet played Batman: Arkham Asylum, I would highly recommend the PC version using either mouse/keyboard or a 360 game controller, especially before the sequel arrives!

Gameplay: This game has a mix of platforming, fighting and puzzle-solving. The platforming is basic, but made interesting with the addition of gadgets; which you can use to pull down walls, get to un-reachable places and more. The fighting system is very deep, and trying to get high combos is always fun. The puzzles are consistently unique, though normally relatively easy.

Story: Arkham Asylum is written like a comic-book, with many classic characters scattered throughout the narrative. There are a few surprising plot twists and occassionally emotional parts.

Graphics: The entire island is very well detailed, filled with easter eggs and secrets. Each area has a great atmosphere and looks very unique.

Sound: The music is on par with the Batman movies (by Nolan) and voice acting is very good.

Re-playability: There are heaps of collectables and lots of extra challenges to attempt.

Arkham Asylum is the only Batman Arkham game so far where you really feel immersed in a major Batman comics story.

Arkham City was the first Batman Arkham game I've played and it's probably going to be the one responsible for my most cherished memories of the series, but so far Asylum has really surprised me as the best Batman experience in a video game ever, even better than City in this regard. Here you meet major foes such as Joker, Harley Quinn and Scarecrow, all with great characterization and dialogues, in a tense and yet damn fun plot in the huge Arkham Island, with a mix of sweet combat and stealth gameplays.

If you're a Batman fan looking for a Batman game, start by this one and you won't regret it one bit.

If I had anything bad to say about this game, it'd be nitpicking the boss fights and the overall length. Honestly, though, it's just that: Nitpicking. This is a fantastic game, and not just a fantastic Batman game...\n\nBut you already knew this, didn't you?

Being a life long fan of batman and comic book heroes this game ticks every box for me.  Although the sequel arkham city" surpasses it in almost every way i still prefer this one of the two.  Why? I have already beat and played the meatloaf out of Arkham City, and Origins.  That being said, Batman: Arkham Asylum is kinda far off.

Let's not get anything wrong here.  Playing as Batman is simply amazing.  You really get that feel of Batman as you glide from gargoyle to gargoyle, and dangle people from a rope that's attached to the gargoyle.  However, Arkham Asylum's controls and game mechanics are far off than City's.  Gliding is practically non-existant, and when there is enough space to glide, you can't grapple onto anything mid-flight.  This is rather frustrating, because you often can't get the drop on a baddie unless you flop on the floor first, then grapple.  The fighting is almost identicle.  You can land hits from 20 feet away, and just punch those baddies until they drop.  The biggest con I found however, was the story.  I had a hard time following the story, and there hardly was one.  The ending felt empty and un-rewarding, unlike City's ending which made you feel like crying into your pillow.

This is a nice addition to the other two, and it's where the series started.  I highly recammend this title, except not for the $30 price range.  Wait until it's on sale, around $10.  You will get all the thrills of being The Batman, however not as much as you would playing the other two additions to the series.

When it comes to video games about superheroes Batman: Arkham Asylum ranks very highly on the list providing a unique experience unlike any that came before it, quite possibly making it the best Batman game ever created.

In Arkham Asylum you play as the Batman who is bringing the Joker back to the asylum from his last escape, however things do not feel right and as sure as bat senses tingle the Joker escapes but this time to take control of the asylum with the help of Harley Quinn and various other supervillains in a widespread plan to cause chaos, and now that the inmates run the asylum it is up to Batman to stop them.

Plotwise this game works very well, the story has dark tones to it that you come to expect from Batman these days and introduces a bevy of supervillains that Batman must take down all while exploring the more psychological side of heroes and villains and by the end of it the story will leave you satisfied despite the twist and turns that had happened along the way.

The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is masterfully done, using many elements from an amazing combat system that lets you pull off flashy moves and counters with single button presses, a stealth system that is done much better then most stealth games seem to do, allowing you to feel as if you are the Batman, hunting these criminals from the shadows ready to pounce, and also has an odd Metroidvania aspect to it where Batman will get upgraded gear along the way that lets him into more places as you explore the island, and the Riddler has hidden things in the environment for you to find such as trophies and solving riddles by finding things hidden in the background.

With how well designed this game is there are a few things I could nitpick, such as how sometimes the platforming controls get a bit wonky having you fall off if you are not careful, or how the game can at times feel a bit too easy even on the hardest difficulty, but all of my nitpicks are vastly overshadowed, the game is a tight fifteen hours or so to beat with more time needed if you want to do everything such as find all the riddles and complete the combat and predator challenges that will truly put your skills in the systems this game has to the test.

Overall Arkham Asylum is an amazing game, the graphics are top notch and the PC version shows them off even better, with a music score very reminiscent of the Christopher Nolan films, if you have any interest at all in Batman, superheros, or character stealth-action games, this game is ranked highly by me and I recommend it to just about anyone.

I had purchased this a LONG time ago and let it sit around while I was playing other things. I've really regret doing that. This is such an amazingly fantastic game that you will not want to put it down.

Harley Quinn also makes an appearance in an outfit you won't soon forget, as well as a number of other key Batman villains with varying purposes and roles.

The combat system is immensely satisfying, as you level your character up, you gain more techniques to use against enemies (whom you can fight upwards of 8-13 in some instances) and they are all quite useful once you get them into your routine.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough, what an amazing Batman game this turned out to be!

You Don't Play Batman...You Are Batman
Batman: Arkham Asylum  is brilliant in almost every way. From a technical perspective: the game looks great, the animations work mostly well, the textures look great and the audio is brilliant (especially the voice acting). The game mechanics give the players the feeling that they are Batman instead of only playing a character who can be replaced by another. The player can easily take out multiple unarmed enemies, via the freeflow fighting system, but needs to be careful when they are armed (predator mode). These gameplay modes give the game more variety and are incredibly well made. The items are based on Batman's utility arsenal and can be used in a variety of different ways, next to their original purpose. The only thing that could have been better is the story, which is very comicish (even for a game that is based on a comic book), but leads to the better story in  Batman: Arkham City .

Rating: 5/5
