reviewText: Great game based on one of the greatest superheroes of all time--Batman. The combat is immersive; if you ever played Spiderman, the combat mimicks that of Spidey and counter measuring your enemies is very satisfying. Nothing beats dodging and throwing Mike Tyson punches and spin kicks to thugs. Majority of buildings and structures are mountable with your Batlaw to scout areas for enemies or to strategize how to pick them off one-by-one. The latter will apply to situations when there are enemies with machine guns as bullets take a good chunk of Batman's health. Yet this is where it gets fun; you as The Dark Knight can use the Batclaw to mount on a gargoyle and press Y button to hang an unsuspecting thug onto the gargoyle while he screams Let me down!" Others nearby will hear their comrade and rush to him. What do you do? Grapple to the next gargoyle and repeat. You can also take them out silently by sneaking behind them or using certain gadgets. For enemies with only fists and melee weapons
date: you can just zerg in and counter when necessary.\n\nGraphics are amazing as are the movie-like cutscenes. The voice acting is superb. I recommend playing with Physics on. I played with the GTX 295 with Physics set to High and it was outstanding. The game is very fun. Only part what I viewed as tedious was Croc and his lair. Scarecrow was literally creepy and disturbing. Poison Ivy was
hoursPlayed: hot! The final battle to the game's conclusion was a great experience. Simple but challenging.\n\nI'm now playing Arkham City. Plan is to play the whole trilogy and Arkham Knight as soon as it releases."

This is an essential game in any Steam library! When it first came out we had to suffer through Games for Windows LIve. But the GOTY edition is perfect, an absolute improvement.

Gameplay wise this game is solid, once you learn the small nuances you will be flying through fights and feeling like an absolute boss. It's not difficult but it is very engaging!

Story is solid, the writers were on the ball and the game is packed with so many side-stories and mini-plots that you are drawn in and held there.

Graphics, this game might be slightly old but it puts a lot of games to shame with the sheer beauty of it's style. A true landmark of graphics that doesn't sacrifice enjoyment.

An amazing game. You don't have to be an avid Batman fan in order to enjoy this game. The game has a lot of lore you can discover about the specific characters in Gotham.

The game has a great free flow combat system: easy to learn, yet difficult to master.
You'll be constantly switching from beating up a bunch of criminals in the open to being stealthy and trying to take out armed criminals with your gadgets.

There's a lot of collectibles in this game ranging from trophies to audio tapes of some of the most deranged criminals of Gotham.

The visuals are stunning even if the game itself is half a decade old; there's a lot of great atmosphere, even making some parts scary".

The achievements aren't ridiculously hard either; you'll be playing this game for a while if you decide to go 100%

reviewText:
Amazing game. Anything you read online about this game being one of the best is true. But, I strongly recommend you play this installment of the Arkham series before any other, because the games only get better.

Combat: Depending on the hardware you are running, it can be anywhere from erratic and choppy to fluid. If you can hold a steady 30 frames, then you can really appreciate the combat. Upgrades give you more options in how you take down thugs, and boss fights are challenging and rewarding.

Stealth: Stealth missions really require you to stop and think about how you want to handle a room. Be wary of line of sight as well, because if you can see them, they can see you. Note: Not as refined as the next titles in the Arkham series.

Environment: Everything looks and feels like a true Batman story. The environment is dirty and gritty, and you know you're Arkham just by looking around. It's a nice mix of high-security technology and Gothic architecture.

Do recommend, 10/10

So i decided i would try to get into the Batman games, and gave this one a go. i found it very fun. I fully expected a game in which you went in all guns blazing and just killed everything, but what i got was a game where you had to sit up high above everyone, and think about how to tackle a situation. I played this game on normal difficulty and finished it in 12 hours. However that was just the main story, if i went back and found all of riddlers trophies it would take considerably longer, normal difficulty was certainly very challenging, dying many times and getting very frustrated. I played the game with the mouse and keyboard, but would advise on the gamepad if you have access to one, as it can get a bit fiddly when facing multiple enemies.\nOverall this game was very fun, i got it on humble bundle with Arkham City which i will start playing straight away.\nThere is a free roaming element to this game, however it's mostly indoors, with one outdoor area, that isn't entirely massive.
Great story, awesome combat would really recommend this game if your a dc fan :)

Once having the vile GFWL attached, Arkham Asylum now is free of that... thing and has Steamworks. Yay! So how is the game? Great! Unlike it's sequel, AA is a (mostly) linear game where you run around as Batman punching people while trying to stop the Joker from doing what he always does. The combat is superb as are the stealth sections: it makes you feel like you are actually playing as a badass fighter/detective like Batman without it being too easy. Negatives are the boss fights, which are highly simplistic and quite uncreative, and the writing which isn't so much bad as it just doesn't match up with the high quality of the rest of the game. Overall, if you like superheroes, and Batman in particular, get this game. It is worth it. :D

The game isn't really challenging in any way at any point due to easy puzzles and even large groups of enemies not being  a real threat because you can just block-counter each and every attack and not get hit once.
Still, a lot of fun if you just want to sit back and want to enjoy some good gaming moments.
May not be worth the 20 bucks unless you're a fan of batman, but gets dropped to about 5€ every now and then. Can defenitely recommend getting it during the next sale!

reviewText: I think I enjoyed this game more than its successor, at least with regard to its main story.  It was linear, but that seemed to work in its favor.  I'm still trying to find all of the collectibles, which are well-placed and fun.  And this series has the best combat of any third person action game I've played.  My only two complaints: (1) the final boss was a bit of letdown, and (2) the bad guys will disappear for the rest of the game after you defeat them.  It's cool at first, but makes collecting stuff afterwards a bit of a drag.

Arkham Asylum presents a fun experience based off the comic book series. As a whole, this game is comparable to The Dark Knight in terms of quality story, art, and cinematics. The storyline is a series of twists and turns as Batman has to stop Joker while facing off against other supervillains in order to reach Joker. The game is set on Arkham Island both inside the asylum and on the outside grounds. Batman has to fight, sneak, solve, and explore his way using various different actions in the game. As a result, there's a bunch of action and solving gameplay rolled into one. Graphically, the game looks realistic and dark while retaining the comic book quality of each character. Some characters look noticably huge while others have a slimmer trim. The music matches the serious tone well by applying the tenseness of the situation. Batman: Arkham Asylum provides a good blend of comic book storytelling with the multiple playstyles and enveloping graphics and music to the feel of the comics.
This game really does a good job of making you feel like batman.  This is the first game based partially around stealth that I've enjoyed.

reviewText: If you like an action game with mostly hand to hand combat then grab this game. The story and the atmosphere gives you an excellent gaming experience. The combos and animations I especially liked. Although the game is linear, you can choose between several methods and tactics how you want eliminate your enemies. Replayability is good also, but the first try will keep you long entertained if you up to the challenge to find all the 240 hidden trophies and do all the achievements. It did worth it's full price for me so if you can get it on a budget price it's a definitely must have. Have fun!

Batman: Arkham Asylum is the greatest comic book videogame of all time. Batman Arkham Asylum: Game of the Year Edition

Positives:

+ The game has an interesting selection of gadgets to use. There's the batclaw, which is used to pull vent grates off walls, explosive gel to destroy structurally weak areas and the cryptographic sequencer, which allows Batman to overload security terminals and gain access to restricted areas. There's also batarangs and the line launcher, which is a portable device that fires a zip line for Batman.
+ The characters are good, they all have personality except for Batman himself, who seems to be very straightforward and lacking in emotion. Joker is a particular standout and the audio tapes found around the Aslyum shed light on various inmates who are Batman's foes.
+ Decent graphics.
+Game length is anywhere between 20-30 hours or so, depending on how many riddles you solve and your desire to play beat em' up challenge mode.

Mixed:

~ The combat can be fun, but also borderline infuriating at times. Using unlockable Waynetech upgrades, Batman can perform takedown moves, throw enemies and do more critical damage. However, the combat is very unresponsive with regards to countering and in this respect Sleeping Dogs did a far better third person combat system. The fact Batman: Arkham Asylum doesn't detect your counter effectively really lets it down.
~ The Riddler's hidden mini puzzles and items add a nice distraction and diversion to the main story, but at the same time they can be a bit boring if you want to complete them all, even if you discover a Riddler secrets map. It was a nice idea and it does add an element of exploration to the game, but 240 Riddler challenges is a bit excessive. My main gripe is that Batman's detective mode is required to find a lot of these trophies and it's quite annoying to be running around all over the map in black and white vision.

~ The story is not bad, it's just not fantastic either. It's a bit difficult to follow, despite its simplicity. I know that sounds like a contradiction, but it's true. It just seems that at some point I lost focus on the big picture, there were a couple of confusing parts regarding the titan formula which weren't clarified. There is no in-game journal which explains the story.

Negatives:

- The boss fights are more or less the same, using evading dives and batarangs to stun. This pattern is repeated throughout many of the boss encounters, nothing really exciting.
- Downloadable content is a joke, it doesn't add anything extra to the story or any new levels. It merely adds more beat em' up challenges..

Overall Score: 7.5/10

Batman: Arkham Aslyum is definitely not a 9/10 game as Metacritic would claim. But it's still good and it's still fun (plus a little irritating too lol). As the first game in the series I'd say it's well worth playing this, be sure to pick it up on sale where it regularly goes down to $5.
If it's on sale, grab it!\n\nTotally revolutionized the hero action games

Amazing game. Anything you read online about this game being one of the best is true. But, I strongly recommend you play this installment of the Arkham series before any other, because the games only get better.

Combat: Depending on the hardware you are running, it can be anywhere from erratic and choppy to fluid. If you can hold a steady 30 frames, then you can really appreciate the combat. Upgrades give you more options in how you take down thugs, and boss fights are challenging and rewarding.

Stealth: Stealth missions really require you to stop and think about how you want to handle a room. Be wary of line of sight as well, because if you can see them, they can see you. Note: Not as refined as the next titles in the Arkham series.

Environment: Everything looks and feels like a true Batman story. The environment is dirty and gritty, and you know you're Arkham just by looking around. It's a nice mix of high-security technology and Gothic architecture.

Do recommend, 10/10

reviewText: So i decided i would try to get into the Batman games, and gave this one a go. i found it very fun. I fully expected a game in which you went in all guns blazing and just killed everything, but what i got was a game where you had to sit up high above everyone, and think about how to tackle a situation. I played this game on normal difficulty and finished it in 12 hours. However that was just the main story, if i went back and found all of riddlers trophies it would take considerably longer, normal difficulty was certainly very challenging, dying many times and getting very frustrated. I played the game with the mouse and keyboard, but would advise on the gamepad if you have access to one, as it can get a bit fiddly when facing multiple enemies.\nOverall this game was very fun, i got it on humble bundle with Arkham City which i will start playing straight away.\nThere is a free roaming element to this game, however it's mostly indoors, with one outdoor area, that isn't entirely massive.

I would have never of thought I would actually enjoy a Batman game. For some reason I've always had reluctance towards these games, but this game definitely changed that!\nOf course I still hate the fact that you can't literally kill/split/splice in pieces your enemies, all those combos I think would feel a lot more satisfying.\nBut except that, nice looking game, good gameplay, not that many bugs (no game changing ones at least), worthy of a GOTY

I originally looked at this game and thought... ahh it's just a beat em up type thing, not really my sort of thing. I picked it up in a recent humble bundle and I was pleasantly surprised. The voice acting is great (ofc) and the storyline is passable. You have the freedom to roam all over Arkham's island exploring the various parts of the asylum. The combat is very well done and you often have the option to sneak up and take things out if you prefer stealth over brute force although it has to be said once you have the hang of thumping people you may not want to give it up.

It shifts into a fixed perspective for some areas and bosses which caused my other half huge problems when he played. It seemed to play well regardless of whether you chose keyboard and mouse or controller as an input device although it was annoying not being able to redefine keys without exiting the game. There are a ton of collectible items scattered throughout that unlock backstory and extra information and a large quantity of fighting and steath challenges that are unlocked as you progress through the game.

All in all it's a well fleshed out game with plenty to keep you hooked regardless of what aspects you enjoy.

If you haven't played this yet you're missing out on something special.

3D brawler gameplay that actually works combined with the genuine sensation that you ARE the Batman.  It's got all the qualities we've come to know and love the Dark Knight's ongoing mythology for, with a decent roster of Gotham's criminally insane lining up to take their shot at the Bat.  The story is beefed up with an excellent script and voice acting fit for the ages.  Mark Hamill's out-of-the-box psychotic Joker brings a wry smile to your face with every one-liner.

Arkham Asylum's gameplay is semi-immersed in stealth.  Enemies who are armed with guns are dangerous if faced directly, so the game teaches you how to move around and take out foes one by one.  Difficulty is scaled up with the acquisition of more gadgets, so adaptation of new techniques becomes paramount to Batman's survival - as it should be.

A special mention is deserved for the game's audio and visual presentation which pump a gritty, suspenseful atmosphere into  the experience.  Arkham Asylum could have easily faultered on these qualities, but it doesn't.

There is really no excuse for you not to have played Arkham Asylum.  Nobody expected it to do what it does with such grace and respect for its source material.  Just buy the bloody thing and play it if you haven't already; you'll soon realise what all the fuss is about.

On one hand, the combat features are incredible. There is a large amount of moves you can do while in a fight, specially if you make big combos. I don't quite know what it is but there is something about the sound it makes when you hit a thug or break his leg that brings that feeling of accomplishment towards the game and makes you play more.

On the other hand, the stealth/predator mode lacks the silence and discretion I expected. The takedowns, except for the silent one are very noisy and attract almost all the prisoners to the location where it happened. There are also a lot of features that in the end make the game to easy in that area. The fact that the sonic batarang always attracts one and only one thug so you can take him down is kind of a buzz kill. In addition to that, if you want, you can easily take down three guys at the same time by using the multiple batarang and the ground pound once they are down, what makes the stealth unchallenging.

The challenges are a great feature of the game and are nice to play even after you finished the campaing.

To sum up, really good game even with small flaws in some areas.

reviewText:
The original and still the best in the series.

It's more focused environment leads to a more tightly crafted game that just begs to be explored. While the later games in the series offer a more open ended approach with arguably more things to see and do, in practice they seem to offer little more than filler between heavily scripted events. While collectibles, secrets and side missions often feel like chores in the later games, they feel like meaningful reasons to fully explore the asylum with appropriate rewards on offer. Each area is filled with unique assets and small, rememberable details. The riddlers side missions task you with photographing scenes that are unique to various characters from the Dark Knight universe which helps to direct the player toward these specially crafted, and unique in-game assets.

The combat system, while arguably too simplistic, is a delight to control as you see Batman stringing insane combo's together effortlessly disarming, and countering incoming attacks. Every kick, punch, grapple and counter is animated well making fights seem appropriately realistic and violent. The combat is assisted by some excellent audio leading to some satisfying crunches, cracks, and smacks as bones break and fists collide with faces.

The metroid-vania aspects of the game are implemented well, with each upgrade offering the oppertunity to revisit locations throughout the game.

The story is well told and the voice acting is excellent throughout, although I felt the final parts of the story were anticlimactic with the final boss fight in particular being tedius and frankly, rather silly. Seeing the Joker turn into a roid-raged meathead seemed rather out of character, and a little far-fetched - even for a comic book super villain.

On a technical level, the game still looks great to this day and runs exceptionally well. A mid-range pc should be able to run this game on maximum settings with a solid 60fps.

All-in-all it's a ground breaking game and in my opinion one of the best games of it's generation. A true masterpiece.
You're Batman.
An amazingly polished, finely crafted piece of action gaming excellence that's worthy of the name Batman.

Once having the vile GFWL attached, Arkham Asylum now is free of that... thing and has Steamworks. Yay! So how is the game? Great! Unlike it's sequel, AA is a (mostly) linear game where you run around as Batman punching people while trying to stop the Joker from doing what he always does. The combat is superb as are the stealth sections: it makes you feel like you are actually playing as a badass fighter/detective like Batman without it being too easy. Negatives are the boss fights, which are highly simplistic and quite uncreative, and the writing which isn't so much bad as it just doesn't match up with the high quality of the rest of the game. Overall, if you like superheroes, and Batman in particular, get this game. It is worth it. :D

reviewText:
When it comes to video games about superheroes Batman: Arkham Asylum ranks very highly on the list providing a unique experience unlike any that came before it, quite possibly making it the best Batman game ever created.

In Arkham Asylum you play as the Batman who is bringing the Joker back to the asylum from his last escape, however things do not feel right and as sure as bat senses tingle the Joker escapes but this time to take control of the asylum with the help of Harley Quinn and various other supervillains in a widespread plan to cause chaos, and now that the inmates run the asylum it is up to Batman to stop them.

Plotwise this game works very well, the story has dark tones to it that you come to expect from Batman these days and introduces a bevy of supervillains that Batman must take down all while exploring the more psychological side of heroes and villains and by the end of it the story will leave you satisfied despite the twist and turns that had happened along the way.

The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is masterfully done, using many elements from an amazing combat system that lets you pull off flashy moves and counters with single button presses, a stealth system that is done much better then most stealth games seem to do, allowing you to feel as if you are the Batman, hunting these criminals from the shadows ready to pounce, and also has an odd Metroidvania aspect to it where Batman will get upgraded gear along the way that lets him into more places as you explore the island, and the Riddler has hidden things in the environment for you to find such as trophies and solving riddles by finding things hidden in the background.

With how well designed this game is there are a few things I could nitpick, such as how sometimes the platforming controls get a bit wonky having you fall off if you are not careful, or how the game can at times feel a bit too easy even on the hardest difficulty, but all of my nitpicks are vastly overshadowed, the game is a tight fifteen hours or so to beat with more time needed if you want to do everything such as find all the riddles and complete the combat and predator challenges that will truly put your skills in the systems this game has to the test.

Overall Arkham Asylum is an amazing game, the graphics are top notch and the PC version shows them off even better, with a music score very reminiscent of the Christopher Nolan films, if you have any interest at all in Batman, superheros, or character stealth-action games, this game is ranked highly by me and I recommend it to just about anyone.

reviewText: Second best Batman simulator after the SNES game.
Amazing game.
Fantastic game. Combat is top notch. The voice acting is perfect. Arkham Asylum is everything you want to see in a comic book game.

Finally got around to playing this, and I don't know what took me so long. This is brilliant. Batman as he always should have been. The game plays out like a 3D Metroidvania, rewarding exploration with tons of secrets to find, most of which you won't be able to get until Batman gets new abilities. The fighting system is fun and fairly intuitive, but the stealth mechanics are my favorite - the experience of being Batman has never come more alive than when I stalked my enemies from the shadows. The music never really spoke to me, but the art and presentation is excellent. The acting is exceptional on all sides, but Mark Hamill's Joker steals the show - as he should.\n\nBEST PART - Picking off a group of thugs one by one while they have no idea where I am, and the baddies left standing get more and more terrified.

I was skeptical about this game when my friend first told me to get it. I'm not a fan of fighting games, and while I think Batman is both on of the best superheroes and one of the most interesting ones, I didn't really think a game like this--developed originally for the Xbox 360 and ported to PC--would do well. Boy was I wrong. Not only are the graphics surprisingly good, the audio (voice acting, fighting sounds, etc.) makes me feel like Batman. In particular, the voice acting is definitely some of the best I've heard in a video game. The fighting, though rather redundant, is still incredibly fun, though I did notice that countering enemy attacks was difficult. I may have been bad at it, but since I'm fine with it in the sequel to this game, Batman: Arkham CIty, I think it may have just been a minor issue in this game. The boss fights, while redundant, are quite fun and actually quite challenging. Furthermore, the story of this game is remarkably good. I never felt like I was playing through a fighting game with a story tacked on; it felt like a fighting game built around the story, in a good way. The atmosphere was top-notch and made me feel like Batman.

To summarize:
Pros-great atmosphere, solid gameplay, good graphics and audio, surprisngly good story, delivers an authentic Batman experience
Cons-Issues with countering, boss fights can be redundant, hard to get used to

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game.

Despite never being a fan of the DC Universe I always heard and thought great things about Batman Arkham Asylum. I was surprised when I first played it really hooked me up. The combat was probably the thing that got me most excited, it felt so satisfying to just punch guys in the face and do all those crazy moves. Another thing I really liked is that despite Arkham Asylum having a linear story they do give you the feel that you are allowed to go anywhere you want in Arkham Island and explore, I really appreciate when they do that and as you unlocked more gadgets backtracking came into place in case I wanted to get all the trophies and solve all the riddles which I actually didn't. The graphics are pretty good looking and I really like the grim atmosphere of the Asylum. Ocasionally there are some puzzle" and stealth sections which I think they are important because they bring someone of a variety to the gameplay. Despite the enemies kept being the same over and over I feel like the boss battles made up for it. That said I really enjoyed my time with Batman Arkham Asylum but I really couldn't be bothered with getting all the collectibles and playing each challenge but overall I do think it is a great game."

The first game in the Arkham Series, Arkham Asylum is nothing short of brilliant.  The plot revolves around Batman trapped in Arkham Asylum, run by the Joker. Along the way Batman fights to survive, and questions his sanity. He questions if he should be in the Asylum himself. Along the way he meets members of his great rouges gallery. The voice actors are brilliant. Kevin Conroy is great reprising his role as Batman from BTAS or Batman the Animated Series. In my mind, he is the one true Batman. Mark Hamill is hilariously dark as the Joker also reprising his BTAS role. You can see the fun these men are having playing their roles, and you can totally buy there long infamous history. The character designs are spectacular, the best being the Scarecrow.  As far as gameplay goes its top notch.  In the story there are some difficult parts, but I being a casual gamer, dont think  many gamers will have much trouble. I'd give the game a 10/10, but the thing that does not make it reach that is the sheer formulelic boss battles. I'm not a huge gamer, but when you add one small differnce to every boss battle, I was never suprised. the final boss battle is  the worst part of the game, in the sense that the game throws everything at you, which makes it seem really far from the brilliance of the first part of the game.


An great expirence. 9 out of 10

Still the best Batman game in the Arkham series and probably the best Batman game ever made. The story involves Batman catching Joker easily after a recent robbery and, coincidentally, Joker's gang moved to the Asylum because of an issue at the Blackgate Prison - once inside the Asylum, the Joker escapes and taskes control of the Asylum and prepares to unearth something far worse than what you initially suspect. You play as Batman trying to unearth this plot and once again stop the Joker.

To this day, this game still has amazing visuals, Batman himself covering around half the screen, looks the part and stands strong and confident as the character should as well as the texture work on his suit are top notch - the rest of the game fairs the same, since the game has been given an outstanding amount of care and work into every area you go through. Not one area in the game feels exactly the same as another even if they look similar. Very stellar work of textures all around overall.

Batman Arkham Asylum is one reason why I like the superhero genre games. The reason being that is that you play as the Dark Knight himself and using his gadgets. The synopsis of the game is Batman captures The Joker and brings him to Arkham Asylum to be kept there, but all along it was a trap as Joker wants to takeover the Asylum for himself. The Joker escapes from his captivity and is on the loose. Now the Greatest Detective has solve this problem by trying to find the Joker within Arkham Asylum and ask him what he really want to do.\nThe gameplay is amazing with features like Detective Mode which makes you see everything in X-Ray vision but it useful to see if there is any of Joker's Thugs is in the room. The abillty to use the batarang is amazing and to use the Batclaw which can bring down walls.\nOverall I think that this game is worth a buy if you are a Batman fan or if you like stealth and beat'em up genres.

Thouroughly enjoyed this game, I had previous experience with this game a few years ago but only now had the motivation to complete the story. The combat is fluent but can be repititive but still manages to stay satisfying, especially when using the batclaw for finishers and extended combos. Graphics are great for the time it was released and showed very little graphical errors (though some pixelation during the final cutscene). The riddler adds a lot of exploration and keeps your eyes open for anything and everything, not to mention spending a hell of a lot of time circling your camera around rooms in detective mode to find riddler trophies. The main plot had little depth but the riddler and the colectibles you gather than tell individual character stories are very promising for anyone who enjoys a thourough story. I'm yet to try any of the other modes but I can definitely recommend the game for its generally satisfying gameplay and interesting start to the Arkham game series.

Amazing !

Deep and interesting story, appealing graphics with a good atmosphere and entertaining gameplay make for an intense and awesome game.
And last but not least: It's BATMAN !

-> 9,5/10

Story (9/10):

Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best games I have ever played.  You play, as the title suggests, as *dramatic pause* Batman!  Armed with many iconic gadgets like the batarang, grapple, smoke bombs, and many more, it is your mission to put a stop to the Joker's plans within the Asylum.

The story is exciting, and unique.  As you progress, you must adapt and master new skills as objectives become more difficult to complete.  Iconic characters will make appearances as you progress.  Most will try to kill you, some will try to pull a fast one and try to backstab you, still one in particular will even try to eat you.  You will be in danger from start to finish, captivated by the eerie environment and developing story.

Visuals (10/10):

Arkham Asylum is a bit dated now, so the graphics are not considered as stunning as they once were.  However, maxed out, it still looks very good.  The asylum is true to its comic book origins, meaning it is dark, depressing, and gives off the feeling that something more sinister is lurking behind the walls than just the criminally insane.

Gameplay (10/10):

The world of Arkham Asylum is free exploration, but to stay interested and invested in the game, you can't really deviate from the story because the story is linear and without side missions to distract you.  Personally, I am not bothered by this because there is quite a bit of problem solving and each area you enter presents a new challenge that require different approaches, so you aren't doing the same thing over and over.

The main story is fairly long probably about 15 to 20 hours depending on the difficulty.  On top of that, you have a couple of miscellaneous “missions” like doing all of the Riddler Challenges and examing the artifacts found in the Asylum.  While many find these boring, I personally enjoyed going back and doing these because they offered sereral easter eggs by referencing events and characters from the comics that I enjoyed.  If this isn't your kind of thing, it is easily skipped.

This game is in third person, so it relies on a very effective free-flow combat system based on combos.  It mixes classic fighting with silent takedowns and special combo moves that create the classic Batman that can take anyone in a fight.  Included in the fighting system are the gadgets.  The gadgets create a whole new host of ways to creatively finish off opponets in both direct and indirect combat.

Many complain about the fact that the Batmobile and Batwing are not present in the game except for short stints, and are not even player operated.  While this is unfortunate, the nature of the game taking place inside a small, finite area really defeats the use of either one.

Sound (8/10):

In terms of music and sound effects, Arkham Ayslum employs them to great effect.  While the soundtrack isn’t really memorable, the small things like dripping water, metal clanking against metal, and other small things add to the immersion.  The environmental and combat sounds are actually quite good.  Unfortunately the dialogs are hit or miss, which sometimes hurts the characters.

Replay value (9/10):

While the plot is linear and there aren't any choices which would change the story in any way, the game provides countless hours of fun as probably the best batman simulator on the market.  If the story mode gets boring, there are always the numerous challenge missions that are not part of the story that are fun to play.

Conclusion (9.2/10):

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a very good game, with an unforgettable setting, an engaging plot, and a loose ends that set up future games.  Overall, it is definitely one of those games which you have to play at least once and I highly recommend it.
Excellent game, highly recommended.

The first installment in the Batman: Arkham franchise has a different feel from the sequels.  Arkham City and Arkham Origins are both great games in their own right, and I think Arkham City is my absolute favorite so far, but Arkham Asylum has a unique combination of unexpected pace changes and foreboding atmosphere that make it a very special game.  I only recently started my second playthrough and am enjoying it all over again, after having spent a lot of time playing the sequels.  I think it's the best entry to the franchise - wait for a sale if you're unsure about whether you'll like it, but I recommend you give it a try.

Soviet's Fast Reviews
Visuals
+ Graphics look smooth and have decent amount of texture detail
+ Animations of characters and combat are fluid and look organic
- Certain areas have flat textures
- The game is often too dark and some things blend into each other

Gameplay
+ Controls feel solid and performing combo moves is fairly easy
+ Glide mechanic and gadgets are fun to use and feel solid
- Some of the voice acting feels stiff and doesn't really fit the situation at certain moments
- Missions are all over the place and can be tedious to run between buildings

Overall
Batman Arkham Asylum throws you right into the eyes of Bruce Wayne/Batman as he transports the Joker to the criminal institution known as Arkham Asylum. The story is quite rich and introduces various characters from the comic books as well as some pretty cool features like the Detective Mode which lets you see the enemies through walls, items hidden in cracks, and switches to activate. Combat is smooth, though the limited combo list can make the constant fight sequences seem a bit tedious. Despite its age and the launch of other sequels, Arkham Asylum is still very fun to play and the story is definitely one of the best of any franchise to date. If you're looking for a great superhero title, check Arkham Asylum on your list of games to purchase.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a piece of diamond among the action games. As a Dark Knight, you will be forced to fight your way througout the mass of enemies and DC supervilllians. Combat is really enjoyable and game itself is pretty much fluent - there is always something going on and you just dont stuck at one place...not even for a while. I recommend this game especially for Batman fans, since you will encounter many villians you are familiar with. In addition with a great dark and intense atmosphere of the Arkham Island, you really gonna believe that you are Dark Knight himself, totally consumed by the great story and characters. As a fresh addition to game, you are able to scout the island and explore all dark corners of it - finding more content like Riddler´s mazes and messages related to history of Arkham City and also background of mentioned Supervillians. In summary, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a natural choice for every fan of action games and keen admirers of a Dark Knight. What else to say? Maybe just...Riddle me this, riddle me that. Who s afraid of big black bat?

Pluses
+ Great atmosphere and fluent story
+ Enjoyable combat and option to improve your Dark Knight (gadgets, armor, battle technics)
+ Decent graphics
+ Nice music, soundtracks and audio in general

Minuses
- You are practically locked up in one place all the time. Although the island itself is kinda interesting and offers a several places to go, the world could be a little bigger.
- Bosses battles (fight strategy and flow of the battle) are kinda repeatable.

Overall: 9/10

Finally got around to playing this, and I don't know what took me so long. This is brilliant. Batman as he always should have been. The game plays out like a 3D Metroidvania, rewarding exploration with tons of secrets to find, most of which you won't be able to get until Batman gets new abilities. The fighting system is fun and fairly intuitive, but the stealth mechanics are my favorite - the experience of being Batman has never come more alive than when I stalked my enemies from the shadows. The music never really spoke to me, but the art and presentation is excellent. The acting is exceptional on all sides, but Mark Hamill's Joker steals the show - as he should.\n\nBEST PART - Picking off a group of thugs one by one while they have no idea where I am, and the baddies left standing get more and more terrified.

I was skeptical about this game when my friend first told me to get it. I'm not a fan of fighting games, and while I think Batman is both on of the best superheroes and one of the most interesting ones, I didn't really think a game like this--developed originally for the Xbox 360 and ported to PC--would do well. Boy was I wrong. Not only are the graphics surprisingly good, the audio (voice acting, fighting sounds, etc.) makes me feel like Batman. In particular, the voice acting is definitely some of the best I've heard in a video game. The fighting, though rather redundant, is still incredibly fun, though I did notice that countering enemy attacks was difficult. I may have been bad at it, but since I'm fine with it in the sequel to this game, Batman: Arkham CIty, I think it may have just been a minor issue in this game. The boss fights, while redundant, are quite fun and actually quite challenging. Furthermore, the story of this game is remarkably good. I never felt like I was playing through a fighting game with a story tacked on; it felt like a fighting game built around the story, in a good way. The atmosphere was top-notch and made me feel like Batman.

To summarize:
Pros-great atmosphere, solid gameplay, good graphics and audio, surprisngly good story, delivers an authentic Batman experience
Cons-Issues with countering, boss fights can be redundant, hard to get used to

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game.

Batman Arkham Asylum easily one of the best superhero games ever made.

Being the first in the series of Batman games in Rocksteady's series of Batman games, it could be easy to dismiss the first as a less refined version of the later games. While later games added features, sometimes at the expense of everything working exactly as planned, Asylum lives up to its early hype as a solid, rhythmic action game with plenty of engaging and entertaining distractions. Great voice acting, fun inclusion of many of Batman's rouge's gallery along side the solid gameplay make it a no brainer, even with Akham Knight on the horizon.

Being a life long fan of batman and comic book heroes this game ticks every box for me.  Although the sequel arkham city" surpasses it in almost every way i still prefer this one of the two.  Why? Perhaps the more comic book style of the menu systems or the more linier path the story takes but mainly i think its being able to explore such an iconic landmark of the DC universe.  Whether you are your a fanboy like me or just enjoy a great action/beat em up/strategy game with a great story then look no futher people!!"

As the graphics, plot, audio, and Epic cinematics and scenery excel in this classic hero and villain story of batman.
I never really thought who was the main antagonist in this game, Batman: Arkham Asylum Game of the Year Edition. It felt like Joker like always would be the role of the villain but then came Scarecrow. He plays these undescive tricks on your brain with his virulent fumes that help you not to tell you who you are. During an 8th of the game you don't even know who you are! All i'm saying is that if i were to choose the most antagonistic villain it would be Scarecrow for this game, but i haven't seen or played Arkham Knight yet. Main fact is this game is by my knowledge and understanding of the previous games this one has earned the right of the GOTY Edition.

Игра класирана в Книгата на рекордите на Гинес в номинация игра за супергерои и получи най-висок рейтинг в историята на компютърните игри. Екип от разработчици от Rocksteady Studios управляваните успя да направи една игра, която е добре приета, дори и тези, които в действителност не са фенове на Батман - преди това играта не може да се похвали с такъв успех и популярност. Rocksteady първоначално се приближи този проект с акцент върху качеството, с особено внимание и грижа, като се вземат предвид всички малки детайли и подробности Девет години история на комикси и адаптации на Батман, и по този начин се създаде ново ниво на качество в областта на компютърните игри. В Arkham Asylum ние сме свидетели на един доста брутален Батман, тактичен, разумно хищен и наистина мрачна ситуация. Тъй като това допринася за доброто съвпадение звуков компонент. В играта има отлична система за борба, има елементи на стелт, изкуствени опоненти и разузнаване в режим на хищник е доста добър. Решавам пъзели на Гатанката, много забавна игра. В играта има своя собствена индивидуалност, целостта на сюжета и неговата доставка. Игра на 2009 г., която ще надмине много съвременни занаяти.\nRocksteady поставила за цел, да направи най-добрата игра на всички видео игри на Батман и те успяха.\nШедьовър! 10 от 10.

So I always heard good things about the Batman Arkham games, but never got to play them. Last week I installed and played the copy of Batman: Arkham Asylum I had lying on my endlessly growing Steam backlog for the first time. After 30 hours of gametime, which included beating the campaign on both normal and hard difficulty, collecting all of the Riddler challenges, getting 3 stars on all the extra challenge mode games, and acquiring all of the achievements, I can confidently say that B: AA is one of the best games I ever played in a long time.

I just want to preface the upcoming gushing I'm about to lay down by saying I love metroidvanias, am not very proficient in high execution gameplay, enjoy a good collect-a-thon, and think Batman is the ♥♥♥♥. This game pushed so many of the right buttons for me as a result.

The best description I can give for the gameplay is that it’s the perfect Batman experience. You can do most of the typical kind of platforming tricks you see in modern 3D action adventure games like in the Assassin Creed games but as Batman you have a variety of tools like a grappling hook that clings on almost all climbable ledges and a cape that helps you glide over larges distances. I found going around the titular asylum a very enjoyable experience, especially the occasional pure platforming and Scarecrow sections you’re encounter throughout the campaign.

The combat is probably the best part of the game. It really feels like you’re playing out a fight scene in a Batman cartoon or movie. It’s very simple to jump around the area pummeling your foes but you need proper timing and twitchy fingers to avoid getting hit and keeping your combo score up. You get a lot of tools and techniques that make the combat a breeze later on but I found myself being tested in some hard mode gauntlets and the dedicated challenge modes you unlock later in the game. Climbing on the larger titan enemies and forcing them to smack around the smaller goons is always a satisfying experience.

The predator sections where you have to stealthily take out a bunch of armed enemies in a huge room is fun. Pure fun. There are so many ways to dispatch them that they made a dedicated game mode for it. And the way the goons start getting freaked out after you pick them off is hilarious as ♥♥♥♥. Like I said, a very Batman-like experience.

While the campaign is pretty linear, there are a ton of collectables sprinkled throughout the island. In a way this game is pretty metroidvana-like in that aspect, as you can backtrack to older areas and use the new items you acquire as you progress through the game to find even more secrets.  While the trophy collecting was pretty basic, the riddles sprinkled throughout the world are brilliant. I got a kick out of finding all of the solutions. You’ll also find these little perspective puzzles that require you to find 2 parts of a question mark hidden on the architecture and align them with your camera so they look whole. It’s hard to explain but they were cool.

The game is a visual and audible treat. The game looks very good, especially for an early-to-mid last gen game. I love all the minute detail for the world, like how Batman gets more visually damaged and grows a stubble as the campaign goes on. All the classic Batman characters get a gritty look that makes them look pretty badass (even though Batman still is wearing his underwear on the outside).  Getting some of the voices from the old animated series was pretty cool. Can’t say no to Steve Blum either.

/gush

Now, I do have some gripes with the game, though. You more and less fight the same kinds of goons throughout the game. The boss fights aren’t very good either, especially the final boss fight. Spoiler: I don’t like that you’re basically have a generic video game-like fight with a huge monster version of the Joker instead of an elaborate battle of wits that you see in other Batman works. It just felt out of place is all.

Anyway, I love this game and I am so looking forward to playing Batman Arkham games in the future.

The first installment in the Batman: Arkham franchise has a different feel from the sequels.  Arkham City and Arkham Origins are both great games in their own right, and I think Arkham City is my absolute favorite so far, but Arkham Asylum has a unique combination of unexpected pace changes and foreboding atmosphere that make it a very special game.  I only recently started my second playthrough and am enjoying it all over again, after having spent a lot of time playing the sequels.  I think it's the best entry to the franchise - wait for a sale if you're unsure about whether you'll like it, but I recommend you give it a try.

Deep and interesting story, appealing graphics with a good atmosphere and entertaining gameplay make for an intense and awesome game.
And last but not least: It's BATMAN !

-> 9,5/10

Batman Arkham Asylum: Game of the Year Edition

Positives:

+ The game has an interesting selection of gadgets to use. There's the batclaw, which is used to pull vent grates off walls, explosive gel to destroy structurally weak areas and the cryptographic sequencer, which allows Batman to overload security terminals and gain access to restricted areas. There's also batarangs and the line launcher, which is a portable device that fires a zip line for Batman.
+ The characters are good, they all have personality except for Batman himself, who seems to be very straightforward and lacking in emotion. Joker is a particular standout and the audio tapes found around the Aslyum shed light on various inmates who are Batman's foes.
+ Decent graphics.
+Game length is anywhere between 20-30 hours or so, depending on how many riddles you solve and your desire to play beat em' up challenge mode.

Mixed:

~ The combat can be fun, but also borderline infuriating at times. Using unlockable Waynetech upgrades, Batman can perform takedown moves, throw enemies and do more critical damage. However, the combat is very unresponsive with regards to countering and in this respect Sleeping Dogs did a far better third person combat system. The fact Batman: Arkham Asylum doesn't detect your counter effectively really lets it down.
~ The Riddler's hidden mini puzzles and items add a nice distraction and diversion to the main story, but at the same time they can be a bit boring if you want to complete them all, even if you discover a Riddler secrets map. It was a nice idea and it does add an element of exploration to the game, but 240 Riddler challenges is a bit excessive. My main gripe is that Batman's detective mode is required to find a lot of these trophies and it's quite annoying to be running around all over the map in black and white vision.

~ The story is not bad, it's just not fantastic either. It's a bit difficult to follow, despite its simplicity. I know that sounds like a contradiction, but it's true. It just seems that at some point I lost focus on the big picture, there were a couple of confusing parts regarding the titan formula which weren't clarified. There is no in-game journal which explains the story.

Negatives:

- The boss fights are more or less the same, using evading dives and batarangs to stun. This pattern is repeated throughout many of the boss encounters, nothing really exciting.
- Downloadable content is a joke, it doesn't add anything extra to the story or any new levels. It merely adds more beat em' up challenges..

Overall Score: 7.5/10

The first game in the Arkham Series, Arkham Asylum is nothing short of brilliant.  The plot revolves around Batman trapped in Arkham Asylum, run by the Joker. Along the way Batman fights to survive, and questions his sanity. He questions if he should be in the Asylum himself. Along the way he meets members of his great rouges gallery. The voice actors are brilliant. Kevin Conroy is great reprising his role as Batman from BTAS or Batman the Animated Series. In my mind, he is the one true Batman. Mark Hamill is hilariously dark as the Joker also reprising his BTAS role. You can see the fun these men are having playing their roles, and you can totally buy there long infamous history. The character designs are spectacular, the best being the Scarecrow.  As far as gameplay goes its top notch.  In the story there are some difficult parts, but I being a casual gamer, dont think  many gamers will have much trouble. I'd give the game a 10/10, but the thing that does not make it reach that is the sheer formulelic boss battles. I'm not a huge gamer, but when you add one small differnce to every boss battle, I was never suprised. the final boss battle is  the worst part of the game, in the sense that the game throws everything at you, which makes it seem really far from the brilliance of the first part of the game.

Still the best Batman game in the Arkham series and probably the best Batman game ever made. The story involves Batman catching Joker easily after a recent robbery and, coincidentally, Joker's gang moved to the Asylum because of an issue at the Blackgate Prison - once inside the Asylum, the Joker escapes and taskes control of the Asylum and prepares to unearth something far worse than what you initially suspect. You play as Batman trying to unearth this plot and once again stop the Joker.

To this day, this game still has amazing visuals, Batman himself covering around half the screen, looks the part and stands strong and confident as the character should as well as the texture work on his suit are top notch - the rest of the game fairs the same, since the game has been given an outstanding amount of care and work into every area you go through. Not one area in the game feels exactly the same as another even if they look similar. Very stellar work of textures all around overall.

I don't say this is the best Batman game out there for no reason - gameplay is pretty basic Brawler" style with very minor puzzle solving

REVIEW: BATMAN: ARKHAM ASYLUM

As I have mentioned in my review of Portal 2, I am behind the times when it comes to the latest games, and one of the many games on my ‘to-play’ list was Batman: Arkham Asylum. Finding it cheap in a store was great, as it meant that I could finally give it a go. But would I find it any good?

In Batman: Arkham Asylum, Batman has caught the Joker (again), but, suspicious at the ease at which the Clown Prince of Crime allowed himself to be captured, Batman decides to escort the Joker to his cell. Unfortunately, the Joker was counting on this. Not only was he planning on being caught and returned to Arkham Asylum, but he planned on Batman being there as well. Batman must fight his way through the asylum, confronting some of his most persistent adversaries, from Bane to Poison Ivy. But what is the Joker after? What is Titan? And can Batman stop the Joker’s plans?

While I’m not that big a fan of the Batman comics in particular, I have read many of the graphic novels, including one that seems to be an inspiration for this game: Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth. That was an intelligent but harrowing mind-screw of a book that clearly inspired more than a few elements. The story, while not at complex epic levels, is good for what it is: a comic book story transferred to a computer game. I’m surprised that, given how Paul Dini (of the serious but still kid-oriented animated series) wrote it, how adult the game seems. Which goes to show my ignorance.

Graphics-wise, the game is beautiful. I am sure that there are more games out there that look better (including Arkham Asylum’s direct sequel, Arkham City, which I am currently playing), but I am not a person who wants their game’s graphics to be ultra-realistic, as long as the graphical style is enjoyable, and that it is. The character design, for the most part, is actually quite excellent, though I am a little bemused at the rather fetishized appearances of Harley Quinn and Poison Ivy, even compared to their comic book versions.

Sound-wise, it is quite immersive and atmospheric. The voice acting is enjoyable, with particular, if predictable, praise going to Mark Hamill as the Joker. I know him more as Luke Skywalker, so to hear him play the Joker is a revelation. The sound effects all work, and the music helps give an edge of dread, without it missing the Elfman/Zimmer edge of the Batman atmosphere.

Gameplay wise, the game is somewhat mixed, although this is partly because this game was developed first and foremost as a console game rather than a PC game. I played on easy simply because of an apprehension I had about the control scheme, and I still found the game challenging, partly because I used a keyboard and mouse as opposed to a controller. That being said, the combat is enjoyable, if a little repetitive, and the Predator Sequences (sequences where one must attack stealthily) are challenging, but in a mostly good way. The gadgets all lend not only to the gameplay, but to the feeling that one is actually Batman. There’s even a few sequences where the World’s Greatest Detective (as Batman is hyped as) actually does some detecting. The sidequests of the Riddler Challenges are actually quite enjoyable and taxing, and nothing beats that little thrill of satisfaction when you beat one of them, and while Riddler accuses you of looking them up on the internet, you actually just found almost all the solutions on your own. My only real complaint, other than the control scheme, is that, even with the Riddler Challenges, the game was over rather swiftly.

Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is an enjoyable game that is really how Batman should be played. Flawed, but still enjoyable and highly recommended.

RATING: ****
Great Batman game

Story (9/10):

Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best games I have ever played.  You play, as the title suggests, as *dramatic pause* Batman!  Armed with many iconic gadgets like the batarang, grapple, smoke bombs, and many more, it is your mission to put a stop to the Joker's plans within the Asylum.

The story is exciting, and unique.  As you progress, you must adapt and master new skills as objectives become more difficult to complete.  Iconic characters will make appearances as you progress.  Most will try to kill you, some will try to pull a fast one and try to backstab you, still one in particular will even try to eat you.  You will be in danger from start to finish, captivated by the eerie environment and developing story.

Visuals (10/10):

Arkham Asylum is a bit dated now, so the graphics are not considered as stunning as they once were.  However, maxed out, it still looks very good.  The asylum is true to its comic book origins, meaning it is dark, depressing, and gives off the feeling that something more sinister is lurking behind the walls than just the criminally insane.

Gameplay (10/10):

The world of Arkham Asylum is free exploration, but to stay interested and invested in the game, you can't really deviate from the story because the story is linear and without side missions to distract you.  Personally, I am not bothered by this because there is quite a bit of problem solving and each area you enter presents a new challenge that require different approaches, so you aren't doing the same thing over and over.

The main story is fairly long probably about 15 to 20 hours depending on the difficulty.  On top of that, you have a couple of miscellaneous “missions” like doing all of the Riddler Challenges and examing the artifacts found in the Asylum.  While many find these boring, I personally enjoyed going back and doing these because they offered sereral easter eggs by referencing events and characters from the comics that I enjoyed.  If this isn't your kind of thing, it is easily skipped.

This game is in third person, so it relies on a very effective free-flow combat system based on combos.  It mixes classic fighting with silent takedowns and special combo moves that create the classic Batman that can take anyone in a fight.  Included in the fighting system are the gadgets.  The gadgets create a whole new host of ways to creatively finish off opponets in both direct and indirect combat.

Many complain about the fact that the Batmobile and Batwing are not present in the game except for short stints, and are not even player operated.  While this is unfortunate, the nature of the game taking place inside a small, finite area really defeats the use of either one.

Sound (8/10):

In terms of music and sound effects, Arkham Ayslum employs them to great effect.  While the soundtrack isn’t really memorable, the small things like dripping water, metal clanking against metal, and other small things add to the immersion.  The environmental and combat sounds are actually quite good.  Unfortunately the dialogs are hit or miss, which sometimes hurts the characters.

Replay value (9/10):

While the plot is linear and there aren't any choices which would change the story in any way, the game provides countless hours of fun as probably the best batman simulator on the market.  If the story mode gets boring, there are always the numerous challenge missions that are not part of the story that are fun to play.

Conclusion (9.2/10):

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a very good game, with an unforgettable setting, an engaging plot, and a loose ends that set up future games.  Overall, it is definitely one of those games which you have to play at least once and I highly recommend it.

Great game. Played it on hard and it took me roughly 25 hours to beat it. Once you're done with the story, you still have a bunch of special challenges to beat (both combat and stealth related) and it doesn't even end there. Then, if you can, you still have a ton of hidden riddles around the asylum that are a lot of fun to find.

As I could not beat the challenges (I warn you, they ARE hard)I uninstalled the game after beating it to the end for the first time, and just a few days ago I decided to install it again (for which I blame Marvel’s Daredevil TV series, which made me want to punch thugs and feel like a superhero once again) and well, I 100%’ed the game this time and can only recommend playing it.  I easily just put another 25 hours in the game, and had a lot of fun along the way. This game *gets it*. You really feel like Batman, the combat flows, the animations are well done, there are no loading screens to speak of, the game looks beautiful and the story and the appearances of the enemies are kind of justified. And, if you want to want to learn more about the characters, you have a bunch of entries about most of them. The gadgets are fun to play with, but I admit that it’s kind of annoying how convenient everything is for Batman. “Oh, I’m stuck in this island… never mind, I have several batcaves in every corner of Gotham, mwahaha!” The game is perfectly adapted to the PC, almost no FPS drops, and if you are Spanish or if you are learning Spanish, I recommend playing it in that language, as the quality of the dubbing and of the translation is extremely well done. I think this is one of the very, very rare occasions in which I prefer a dubbed product rather than the original. But yeah, that’s just my opinion. Anyway, congrats to everyone who participated in the Spanish localization of the game.

And among the best moments of the game, I loved the parts with Scarecrow in them. Extremely interesting and engaging, and trying not to spoil too much, there’s this particular part that resembles the now classic  fight against Psycho Mantis in MGS1. That was genius and I loved it. We need more mind-blowing, scary stuff like that in video games.

I still haven't played Arkham City or Origins, so I really cannot compare them yet with Asylum. However, I must say that I bought them both as soon as I could after finishing this one, so I guess that means asylum is probably worth it…. In fact, it is! If you enjoyed the movies/series/comics, you'll definitely like this game.

So yeah, if you still haven't played any arkham games, you should definitely give this one a go. It's your chance to be Batman, should I really say anything else? *vanishes*

Played through on Hard first try, got about 80% of all of the collectables and secrets (there are hundreds). Very well made game, and rife with awesome Batman info/lore.

The ONLY complaint I have with this game is the combat system. The combat isn't very complicated because there are many parts where you need to neutralize enemies in stealth, as any good Batman should. The problem here is that, because the combat is stretched so thin between straight up fighting and stealth, it does neither perfectly.

STEALTH - Stealth is a very wishy-washy thing in this game, and because everything in a room is illuminated the same, you don't know if you are in hiding or if a gargoyle you've perched on is not actually putting you in the shadows. You can't fight enemies with guns straight up, so you are frequently forced into the stealth role.

HAND-TO-HAND - Much of the straight up combat in this game is luck-based. Not all of it, but enough to be minorly frustrating in Hard mode. There is a 'counter' button while you're fighting that can counter an enemy's basic attack, but the prompt to counter shows up only 50% of the time, and even at that rate, it is very unlikely that you hitting the correct button will actually counter the enemy's attack because you're already in full swing of your own attack.

And here inlies the main problem with this game - the 'difficulty'. Because of these certain flaws in the combat, the way the developers ramped up the difficulty was by not making certain enemies harder, but just simply putting more enemes in the combat with you. That isn't very good game design, in my opinion. Because not all attacks are properly counter-able, the more enemies you're fighting, the more you're at the whim of the randomness of the game and how the enemies approach you. I have often found myself having to replay some battles where I play noticeably worse, but win the overall battle becaue of the random way certain enemes approach or attack you.

Yes, this is a fantastic game, but it's minor flaws turn into glaring ones during certain parts of the game. I would still highly reccomend it, but maybe not for a scaling challenge, but more for batman and adventure / collect-em-all fans.

Not a very long game (about 15 hours), but very entertaining, and very polished.

You can really sense that the developers simply love the comics. Everything is just right: Batman uses his brains, stealth, and gadgets as much as his brawn; he never kills; the villains all act according to their various demented personalities; and Arkham Asylum is full of little nods to many, many characters from the comics.

The gamish aspects are just as polished. The controls (I used a gamepad) are smooth, the graphics are nice, the action (especially the many boss fights) is often challenging but rarely frustrating.

If you like Batman and are looking for an action game, then you can't go wrong with this one.

Superheroes have had issues with past video games, often being inaccurately portrayed or having  glitchy gameplay (I'm looking at you Superman 64). Thankfully though, this game isn't one of them.
You've probably already heard all of the praises being sung over the Batman: Arkham series, so I'll keep this short: This game is amazing.

Wonderful gameplay, fast-flowing action, a bunch of wacky characters to match wits against and enough challenges to keep you busy for quite a while. Oh, and you get to play as Batman of course.
The game consists of Joker taking over Arkham Asylum and Batman having to stop him, battling inmates, rescuing guards and sneaking around taking down thugs in the most Batman ways possible.

Just as the Dark Knight Trilogy defined Batman on film, the Arkham series defined Batman in games, setting a standard to which all future superhero games should aspire to.

BE THE BATMAN ;)

reviewText:
I know I'm very late posting this review, but I'm going to do it anyway.
TL;DR:
Pros:
- Smooth combat system (choice of beat-em-up or stealth)
- Be the Batman. Use his gadgets.
- Learn more Batman lore than you knew existed
- Engaging and new plot
- Dynamic Dialogue
- Appealing art style and graphics

Cons:
- Controls on Mac were a little hard to get used to, but you can change your keyboard bindings, and I believe you also have the option of playing with a gamepad.

Breezy's full review:
Batman: Arkham Asylum is hands down the best video game based on a comic that I've ever played and one of the best games overall in my collection. I remember playing the demo at my local GameStop and being sort of skeptical as it just seemed like another beat-em-up. Flash forward to about 5 years later and I'm so glad that I was wrong.
The story is refreshing and encapsulating. The dialogue is great (a lot of times humorous, a lot of times epic, only sometimes corny). Like everyone else says, the combat system is the most fluid I've seen in a video game, though I much prefer the Predator" style of combat (taking out enemies stealthily) in the game. Being the Batman and getting to use all his gadgets (Batclaw

reviewText: Great craftmanship, great story telling, extremely satisfying combat system, very fun and mind boggling, worth playing again. Great game. I also recommend using a controller.

Rocksteady Studios has made a great job. The plot and way by whom is told are excellent. Moreover, many character bios, audios and awesome riddles makes that I wanted to get them all and spend a lot more time playing it. I admit of being fallen in love with its combat system. It looks awesome and doesn't need to use lots of buttons. Visualy it still keeps very well. Developers have done a great job with the Unreal Engine 3. Music is characteristic to Warner Bros productions. It seems to be taken out from a movie. It matches perfectly to the world of the game and entire plot. The only thing I didn't like is Batman's attitude to gadgets. I don't understand why he couldn't get all of them (except those from upgrades) at one time. Even so, it's one of the best games of the last years and a little of other titles can be placed equally with this Batman.

This is a game I already own for the X-box 360 but it has such a great gameplay I don't mind playing it over and over. The same goes for the other 2 games, soon to be 3, in the Arkham series.\n\nSure the gadgets are the same does the same thing and is used to accomplish the same things throughout the series but I don't mind. I like the games for their action element, story, and lots of things to do beside just following the main script.

All time favourite Batman game
Many Open-world RPG type games still use this game as their benchmark
Graphics still hold up today and the gameplay is fluid as anything if you know what you're doing
Story is well thought out and long enough to enjoy but there is heaps to do once youve finished the story. Even if it is just getting those last Riddler challenges or getting 3 stars on the challenge maps.
Recommend this game to anyone who is even a slight fan of Batman or enjoys a good RPG

Batman: Arkham Asylum is an hybrid between an action and a stealth game taking place in the Batman universe. The plot revolves around Batman capturing the Joker one more time and bringing him to the titular Arkham Asylum, only for him to escape and take control of the facility. Batman must then uncover Joker's real plan and stop him, his henchmen and the super villains he will send against the Dark Knight.\nThe main gameplay is generally splitted in direct combat and stealth or predator sequences. Hand-to-hand combat revolves around the so called freeflow system": in order to bring down a lot of enemies without losing health Batman must hit one enemy after another using his moves and gadgets (and countering enemies' blows when necessary) in the longest combo possible. Later combat sequences are made harder by enemies carrying special equipment that requires you to deploy special countermoves and very though mini-bosses. The predator sequences are instead classical stealth-based encounters: since Batman can't resist agains severe gunfire
date: you are forced to navigate several maps carefully
recommended: picking up enemies one by one without being discovered. You can use your gadgets and vantage points to plan your moves more carefully.\nDefeating enemies allows you to gain experience that can be used to gain "levels": each level unlocks an upgrade point which can be spent in either better equipment or new moves.\nArkham Asylum allows the player to choose from three levels of difficulty: easy
hoursPlayed: normal and hard. The latter offers the greatest jump of difficulty
voteText: since it makes enemies more aggressive and resiliant in combat
helpfulPercent: counterattack icons disappear and gunfire more damaging to Batman.\nThe whole game takes place on the Arkham Island near Gotham: aside from three main hub zones
votesHelpful: the majority of the action takes place inside the facilities of the asylum
votesTotal: like the gardends or the medical bay.\nThe only side quest featured in the game revolves around the challenges the Riddler set up for Batman: these can either be about finding Riddler's trophies hidden in more or less plain sight around the island or scan specific points of the scenary and solve Batman universe-related riddles.\nAside from the main campaign
votesFunny: Arkham Asylum offers a challenge mode too
commentsCount: which is about playing through different combat or predator maps and try to achieve the best possible score and unlocks medals.\nNot only Batman: Arkham Asylum is considered one of the best licensed and superhero game around: it's also a great piece of story from the Batman universe and a very damn fine example of the action genre
